For someone who knows the toughness of military life and regularly makes films about how macho and brave law enforcement is, David Ayer's adolescence is staggering. He needs better squad goals.
The Legend of Tarzan is indistinguishable from the other mediocre blockbusters released this year.
Beyond could have been more interesting and memorable if it wasn't weighed down so heavily by its combat moves.
Rarely has a film looked as jaw-dropping as this while being so poorly served by its screenplay.
The Angry Birds Movie is both the equivalent of a screaming five-year-old and a regressive piece of American propaganda.
While a highly realistic film because of its naturalistic actors, it's equally stylised by providing space for the actors through formal decisions that amplify their emotions.
Everything Money Monster has to say about corporate greed is true but as a film it also leaves no contrivance unturned or untouched.
The failure here isn't from unpacking a troubling historical moment with humour. It's the erratic switches in the tone that confuse the film's mood and intentions.

While it's okay to enjoy big studio films of this size, one shouldn't feel obliged to trudge through them annually and celebrate their mediocrity just because you carry the mantle (or the cross) of a fan.
It is more than a glossy celebrity cover shoot. It has both beauty and brains.

As with the impressive Ex Machina last year, Midnight Special is, despite its flaws, another example of a modern Hollywood sci-fi film using special effects to enhance its story rather than obscuring or overpowering it.
Florence Foster Jenkins is determined to shape its story into a crowd-pleaser but suffers from overexcited, uncontrolled performances and clumsy on the nose scripting.
It probably won't make one hide under the bed, but Bones should more than satisfy horror movie fans, as it employs a believable plot, just-enough spooky elements and a dose of dark humor.
Looks at interracial relationships from a fresh perspective and gives the audience something real to think about.
Death of a Dynasty accomplishes what it set out to do -- to make a few laughs.
Does a good job of capturing the aspect of child-parent and child-adult relationships. And although funny, the movie does touch on a few social issues.
Dark Skies sustains tension by grounding most of the family's torment in reality.
Warmth and charm have almost been sucked dry from this incarnation of Oz and performances are muted, especially Franco, who bumbles through his scenes as if he is making up dialogue on the spot.
Aside from the impressive final showdown, Breaking Dawn - Part 2 feels like the dying breaths of a cash cow being milked dry.
movie_title: The Twilight Saga: Breaking Dawn Part 2 (2012)

movie_review_blurb: The gossamer-thin plot is more flimsy than some of the characters' dresses and at 146 minutes, the sequel overstays its welcome by the best part of an hour.

Crowe's accent roams the British Isles depending on who he is acting opposite, which is distracting, but Blanchett is luminous with an unshakable Nottingham burr, which adds warmth to some choice lines of dialogue.
Polanski polishes the lacklustre material and his impeccable style creates the illusion of suspense where our steady pulse tells us there is none.
The film rocks, but it's not that good.
movie_title: Tenacious D in The Pick of Destiny (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Birth, death, romance, danger: All play a role in Jacquet's homage to a remarkably endearing creature.

A fitting introduction to the very personal cinema of this master craftsman, not only because it exhibits Bergman's signature themes and stylistic devices, but also because it is one of his most life-affirming films.
Despite its compositional flaws, Melvin Goes to Dinner will please anyone who takes the art of social chatter seriously.
An uneven political thriller that suffers mostly from a highly convoluted story line.
The bittersweet mood pervades until the final frames when Hedges contrives a satisfying resolution that should leave a few lumps in throats.
movie_title: The Odd Life of Timothy Green (2012)

movie_review_blurb: A tender, spirited look at love and community in the midst of war.
A haunting, richly textured film that, like the Italian director's unforgettable Lamerica, dramatizes the plight of poverty on an epic scale.
Faux documentary, home movie or unexpurgated family therapy? The Talent Given Us, a funny, surprising ride with a mercurial New York clan, is all three.
[It] quickly descends into a pointless repetition of images and vapid dialogue.
De Oliveira gives us a witty, moving, yet unsentimental study of mortality that ranks among the best work of his career.
The Place Beyond The Pines is impeccably crafted and Mike Patton's orchestrations beautifully underscore the inner turmoil.
The script's philosophical musings about humanity and self-sacrifice are almost as flimsy as the central love triangle that fails to ignite the emotional afterburners for a slam-bang finale.
DeMonaco's script begins to run out of steam ... but there's a deliciously nasty sting in the tail, just when it seems the film is poised to draw breath.
The fractured chronology hampers dramatic momentum but Jordan navigates a clear path between past and present, drawing us into his heroines' unusual predicament.
A frothy and harmless confection that squanders the on-screen talent.
A charming fable that could, with clever parental persuasion, inspire the youngest generation to swap their video games for an invigorating spot of housework.
The shifts in tone between black comedy, romance and suspense are often jarring and Dean's script fails to seamlessly weave together its themes of incest and redemption.
Star Trek Into Darkness is bolted together with clinical precision by Abrams, who orchestrates each daredevil chase and skirmish with breathless abandon.
Diesel and Walker can play their roles in their sleep, and the lack of expression on the former's face suggests he might be ...
Dead Man Down is gripping.
Moore and Lucas's script treats the characters with affection and is peppered with belly laughs.
All Stars is inoffensive wish fulfilment aimed at a distinctly younger audience than the StreetDance franchise.
Quips aside, there's a disappointing lack of depth to the characters.
The film means well, it just doesn't stir the soul.
Fuqua lights the fuse on the summer blockbuster season with an almighty, ground-shaking bang.
[Peddles] a winning formula of fizzing dialogue and longing glances.

Linfield and Fothergill, colleagues from the BBC Natural History unit, who worked together on the series Planet Earth, remain cheerful throughout. Their passion for Mother Nature shines through in every frame.
A film that many will find more morbid than melancholy.
For most ... this will be hard to take, like a warped, nightmarish parody of Mr Bean.
What promises to be a pure candyfloss ghost-train ride filled with ominous noises, creaks and shadows ends with a silly twist that's much more likely to raise eyebrows than goosebumps.
It's an intriguing take on actual diaries kept by women pioneers of the time, but their journey may be as punishing for some viewers as it was for them...
Though the period feel and detail are excellent, the fascinating historical complexities become somewhat lost in a sentimental tale of bloody ties and brotherly duty.
Bean and Danny Dyer butt heads in an engaging manner, and the icy locations add an atmospheric backdrop.
Red Hill has an imagination and intelligence that stays long in the mind.
A strong gimmick, but it doesn't quite hang together as a documentary as well as it might.
movie_title: POM Wonderful Presents: The Greatest Movie Ever Sold (2011)

movie_review_blurb: This is a nicely ragged and offbeat mismatched-buddy movie that, though it becomes a little predictable by the end, makes an unexpected hero of a profoundly irritating character.
A bang-on soundtrack will make the hairs on ex-ravers' necks stand up. The plot will have the opposite effect.
Roland Emmerich's meticulously crafted and often well-acted exposé of the "real" William Shakespeare is shocking only in that it is rather good.
Features great performances and terrific Cold War detail...
Terrific, pulpy stuff.
It's actually an uplifting and thoughtful meditation on judgement, about the presumptions we make about other people's lives.
Rising Italian star Kim Rossi Stuart is the standout in this fast-paced biography of Milanese gangster Renato Vallanzasca, who fancied himself as something of a Robin Hood figure in the mid-1970s.
Well-intentioned but ill-gauged...
This sprawling would-be epic is quickly sunk by flat direction, stilted dialogue and very ill-advised casting.
It's a fascinating but terrifying insight into a very murky world.
It makes a change to see a movie about criminality that doesn't romanticise male bonding and violence.
A rich, understated character drama that gleefully exposes the petty playground politics at the centre of one of the internet-era's most bitter court cases.
The style of the film is often brilliant and always arresting, especially when Dunbar's work is performed by lively local actors on her desolate former stomping ground.
Best of all is Bening, capping even her performance in American Beauty, as a woman forced to face her partner's betrayal.
Leigh completes a most satisfying hat-trick -- following Vera Drake and Happy-Go-Lucky -- with yet another beautifully performed character piece.
When the movie sticks to being a long-form version of the trailer, Machete delivers deadpan laughs and bloody, tongue-in-cheek action thrills.
An intriguing but ultimately niche documentary about the Catch-22 situation facing parents in the matter of their child's education.
Plays out more like a Monty Python comedy than a serious drama, with a subplot involving roller-skating friar-detectives that makes this already turgid 140-minute bore seem a whole lot longer.

Mullan plays his unsympathetic character with power and magnetism, but it is Colman's terrific performance that sticks in the mind, a powerhouse portrayal of one of modern-day suburbia's many unseen, unheard victims.
As a slow-burn, poetic character piece it works just fine, with Dorff and especially Fanning making engaging leads.
Plausible chills are offset by the film's clumsy youth-movie trimmings, which, through lurid visuals and ripe overacting by its largely unknown cast, drain most of the suspense and interest...
A surprisingly fun, effervescent against-the-odds drama that offers an upbeat moral without the usual punishing survival-story clichés. Not for the faint-hearted, mind.
The film hurtles towards an exhilarating and disturbing climax that will please fans of Roman Polanski's early work.
In lesser hands, this could have been clumsy and preachy but, while it's certainly leaden at times, Bardem keeps it on track with quiet, compelling dignity.
A sharp study of corporate greed for those who felt Michael Moore pulled too many punches.
A dark rites-of-passage story meets lethal Shakespearean drama, with low-key performances that artfully get under the skin.
After the excellent Milk, this is more like curdled cheese.
A tough, post-punk Tintin-meets-Klute for the Occupy Wall Street set, this kinetic, hard-edged thriller is the perfect festive comedown for Fincher fans and dysfunctional families everywhere.
movie_title: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Strong cast, disappointing characters and a plot that's as thin as discount plonk.
Hennie's hangdog hero makes this a perversely entertaining ride, even at its most relentless and - particularly for Roger Brown - punishing.
Formulaic, yet scrappy, and extremely funny in fits and starts.
Standard gross-out comedy fare and surprisingly formulaic by Baron Cohen's usual standards.

It goes without saying that it is weird, but even from the director of eXistenZ and Videodrome it is bizarre, with the mannered, affected performances of the former and the outsider characters of the latter.

Brannigan is an engaging lead and Henshaw offers light relief, but director Ken Loach, famous for his social realism, and regular writer Paul Laverty struggle to find a balance between the film's comic and serious elements.

The characters run the gamut from near-comatose to shrill, all of them awful, and what seems to aspire to being a modern comedy of manners is simply a mean-spirited satire on such close but paradoxically unloving families.
A little pretentious maybe, but then you've got to wonder at a woman who could sit motionless in a wooden chair, eight hours a day for three months.
movie_title: Marina Abramovic: The Artist Is Present (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Polley is very good at depicting the small highs and lows of modern relationships - the frequent poignant moments of everyday intimacy will doubtless strike a chord with many couples.
The action's arresting but the dialogue's not much cop in this well-played and enjoyable hardboiled British police thriller.
The film makes a beautiful job of juggling laughs and real drama.
A funny, dirty and very, very violent comedy that tilts at serious themes (as did In Bruges, but in a different way) and does so with a messy, irreverent, gung-ho energy.

Part of the appeal of this affecting and powerful drama is that it puts the viewer right in the moment at every stage, using authentic locations and tsunami survivors to hammer home the reality of this tragedy.
A good, efficient crime thriller, let down by clunky social commentary but lifted by excellent performances, including perhaps Brad Pitt's recent best.
Bursting with insights and a droll sense of the absurd side of fashion, it's a fitting tribute to one of the industry's key figures.
movie_title: Diana Vreeland: The Eye Has To Travel (2012)

movie_review_blurb: An ingenious, witty film that simply brims with ideas and energy.
As horrifying and hard to watch as you'd expect a paedophile's-eye view of life to be. It's neither sensationalist nor trite, and the questions it asks are intelligent and thoughtful.
Although it doesn't quite match LA Confidential for complexity and scale, it does capture some of the grit and dynamism of the author's hard-boiled style.
At its core, there's a provocative story lurking here about the delicate and fragile dividing lines between mind, body and soul.
Evans' film is like nothing else around, an instant cult hit that carries the funky, illicit thrill of the fleapit and serves as an unbeatable reminder of the gloriously disreputable heyday of VHS.
A wonderful, melancholy character piece that's funny and tender, and as fresh as a breath of Oslo sea air.
There's little here to add to the well-worn haunted house genre.
In an age of hubbub, its patient elegance is a rare thing we should nurture.
A heady and often heartrending study of lovers at loggerheads...
[A] beautifully played, precisely observed and surprisingly thoughtful buddy movie, which is based on a true story.
On a gut level, Enter the Void is pretty sensational -- a dense, psychedelic collage of sounds and images that often abandons story altogether to pursue a purely cinematic experience.
Simply irresistible.
The back and forth narrative makes a few plot points hard to follow, but overall this is an artful portrayal of every mother's worst nightmare.
movie_title: We Need to Talk About Kevin (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Simply worthy and dull, revealing little about Suu Kyi's mettle and true feelings or indeed any wider truths about her undeniable impact on the world stage.
An uneven study of a notorious love story, raised by some superb performances and nuances, but brought down by awkward direction.
In its clearer moments, Madonna's handsomely staged film cleverly defies the history books with some provocative points about the price Simpson "really" paid for her notoriety.
Though short on shocks and mild in horror terms, Fresnadillo's fantasy has a lot of heart and sincerity in equal measure.
It is so wilfully off the scale that it is hard to know quite how to quantify it.
This story in itself would be enough, but, like any good modern documentary, The Imposter has more twists and turns to reveal.
An opaque, slow-burning but brilliant thriller about the compulsions of terrorism, one that avoids ideological bombast and looks instead to the experiences of an angry and frightened woman.

The main performances, by non-professionals, would be stunning in any movie, but here they are the icing on a strange and eccentric cake. It's a film so completely unique that it's hard to imagine how it was even made.
Brave, beautifully acted and emotionally revealing - an early strong contender for the most provocative and compelling film of the year.
An intense, claustrophobic experience that's inventively filmed and powerfully performed by Reynolds as the story's flawed but unnecessarily hard-done-by everyman.
The black and white cinematography and unusual sound design combining to haunting effect.
Lawrence's mature and inspiring determination makes this much, much more than a grim skid-row whodunnit.
The Coensâ(TM) first mainstream romantic comedy is a superb hijacking of an ailing art form -- short, sharp and frequently laugh-out-loud hilarious.
Great performances, provocative ideas and gripping action scenes fall prey to Hollywood logic and pat storytelling in the final hour.
Ambitious coming-of-age drama, this may hit a false note here or there but the performances are magnetic.
movie_title: A Guide to Recognizing Your Saints (2006)

movie_review_blurb: A dazzling and exquisitely original riddle as told by an enigma, featuring a superb, multi-layered performance by Laura Dern.
A gross and engrossing attempt to humanise a hot-button subject, using a star-sprinkled cast to reveal some unpalatable truths.
Sam Jackson delivers the electric blues in a not-so-blue movie that promises more Deep South sin than it actually delivers.
This is not a film about narrative but loneliness and life on the road, which it captures with a mysterious brilliance.
An intriguing rites-of-passage story with a delirious, skewed perspective and an almost palpable sexual pulse.
A solid, uncomfortable account of a wife's ordeal, with a strong turn from Jolie, but strangely lacking an emotional focus.

Seriously entertaining American filmmaking and definitely not the half-serious pastiche it could easily have been. No seatbelt, no airbag, no nuthin' - just Tarantino driving wildly under the influence.
A film about creative and emotional burn-out that says more about the fragility of the soul than any montage of ticket sales and 'sold out' signs could ever muster.
A bold and sometimes garbled take on modern American politics, this nevertheless marks an effective and surprisingly funny comeback for a film that many deemed to be DOA.
Van Sant's low-key, experimental high-school drama is an affecting rites-of-passage tale, told with bold style and quiet integrity.
A beautifully rendered, long, drawn-out but ultimately very satisfying story of betrayal and revenge in an uneasy setting of wartime paranoia.
Tense, kinetic, intelligent and real.
Borrowing heavily from leftfield genre spin-offs like True Romance, it's no wonder this misfire was on the shelves for so long.
John C Reilly just about holds together a funny but patchy comedy that puts a ten-megaton bomb under the cliched rock biopic - and never detonates it.
movie_title: Walk Hard: The Dewey Cox Story (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A moving but gritty story of willpower and sacrifice that stops pleasingly short of a Hollywood varnish-job.
A visually stunning Swiftian satire, Children Of Men may appear clumsy, but its message is simple, heartfelt and ultimately rather moving.
An unexpected delight, dealing with intergenerational relationships in a funny and unusual way.
It's The Station Agent's meditation on the smaller things in life that make it such a big deal.
Too dark to be a love story, too light to be a thriller and a touch too long to be either, this is dry, genre-twisting fun for admirers of Leconte's ingenuity.
It's sprawling at times, but still uncomfortable, angry viewing in a time when apathy and resignation rule.
Martin Scorsese's criminally neglected tribute to the heyday of the MGM musical has aged astonishingly well.
Whites debating racial injustice: fine for a book published in Afrikaans a decade ago, but a poor premise for a message movie.
After An American Tale, Bluth surely had the clout to make a more adventurous animated feature than this ...
A black comedy with flashes of genius, but let down by a sharp slide into chaos.
A languid, shimmering mood piece from a master stylist, with some of Asia's finest actors at their peak.
[A] powerful and moving film, a smart study of relationships that could but can't and never will be.
A smart, original neo-noir that works as an ingenious mindgame as well as a slick Hollywood calling card.
A compelling, intelligent and provocative sins-of-the-father story with a terrific ensemble cast, and a standout Mr. Ripley turn by the ever-versatile Gael García Bernal.
Even Jon Lovitz with a Batmobile, a dwarf attack in a playroom, and David Spade's best wig ever can't save this mawkish misfire.
A tender, scabrous and very, very funny comedy that picks up 12 years after the original.
A bold attempt to convey a complex situation that captures the anger and tensions of early-20th century Ireland, but falls strangely short on human drama.
movie_title: The Wind That Shakes the Barley (2007)

movie_review_blurb: What promises to be a provocative account of the late Beatle's involvement with the American underground delivers precious little in this Yoko-approved documentary.
Affleck's meta-satire riffs amusingly on celebrity culture without hitting too many faux-doc highs.
A stylish, darkly satirical horror-thriller, raising serious questions about Hollywood's sanitisation of violence.
A frustratingly soft documentary that would sooner teach the world to sing than get to the bottom of the Bin Laden enigma.
movie_title: Where in the World Is Osama Bin Laden? (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Slight, silly and somewhat familiar it may be, but this off-the-wall comedy has enough freewheeling charm and likeable personality to cover its cracks.

The farce that follows is both ridiculous and surprisingly real, mining a very rich seam of comedy while also making some very sharp points about male friendships and the often very blurred line between straight and gay.
Up in the Air stays clear of genre clichés, offering a satisfying hybrid of 1950s glamour, 70s realism and 21st-century attitude.

Temple tries his best to make the story lively and interesting (even embarking on a brief history of the Thames estuary), but Dr Feelgood remains an R&B band of limited appeal, and Oil City Confidential won't create many new converts.
A barbed study of the American economy puts capitalism in the dock but somehow fails to convict.

Slick, sharp and fantastically entertaining, this is a film that works not just as a cautionary tale about the pitfalls of helping strangers but also on a deeper level as a crafty meditation on art, its true value and our own gullibility.
Tom Harper's feature debut is a wistful and atmospheric drama, with superb performances from Turgoose and especially Grainger.
Tilda Swinton unleashes her diva and Italian cinema gets a powerful new voice in this operatic melodrama.
It's melodramatic stuff, but it's beautifully filmed and Swinton is outstanding.

Though it dwells on the seamier side of showbiz -- a seedy, pill-popping actor and a slutty casting-couch actress turn up in subplots -- it ultimately buys into the fantasy land it had started out debunking.
With jokes that routinely miss the mark and cringeworthy slapstick, this black comedy farce shouldn't work. Somehow, though, it does.
Fond and very funny homage to the exploitation era.
Enjoyable stylistically, but not substantiated beyond glossy advertisement.
Taut, tightly-plotted and at times confronting, it'll have you gripping the arm of your seat and double-locking the door.
A welcome change from the increasingly irony-enriched fare we've come to expect.
A hard film to love, but a hypnotic meditation on all the elements - gossip, religion, bullying - that can turn a parish and country bad.
With In Bruges, the British gangster movie gets a Croydon facelift. It may not be new, but it's a wonderfully fresh take on a familiar genre: fucked-up, far-out and very, very funny.
Ang Lee's latest dissection of the American dream is one of his most complex and even most deceptively subversive films.
George Clooney dazzles and Jeff Bridges shines in a scattershot but often hilarious military farce.
movie_title: The Men Who Stare at Goats (2009)

movie_review_blurb: A slick, fun film that has by no means sacrificed the fast action beats of the first three.
movie_title: Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull (2008)

movie_review_blurb: A sombre, slow, but well-paced study of organised crime in urban Naples that leaves a very grim taste in the mouth.
A clumsy, clichéd morality play that may actually represent the lowest point of Allen's recently chequered career.
A compelling, adult period thriller, with an Oscar-assured performance from Angelina Jolie.
Very humane portrait of a potentially extremely unlikeable character.
Anchored by a great Giamatti performance, Cold Souls is built around a terrific idea and has serious fun with it. It also marks Barthes as a filmmaker to watch.

Up is a more more classic piece of entertainment, which cleaves to the Pixar template of being beautifully rendered, emotional and laugh-out-loud adult funny, all the while capturing the naïve charm of old-school Disney.

It's not a catastrophe, but neither is it a classic, and a big problem is Coppola's self-penned script, an Oedipal drama that may as well be subtitled An Oedipal Drama, because subtlety is not its strongest suit.
Air Doll looks beautiful, and even though it bordered heavily on pretension, I went with it and was happy to give Kore-Eda the benefit of the doubt.
A Prophet is an astonishingly detailed crime drama that could end up being this year's Gomorra, but although it's arguably more accessible.
It's elegant, witty, tightly plotted and absolutely gripping.
Funny, sometimes tender and ultimately unsettling black comedy.
Drag Me To Hell is never less than trashy, adrenalised fun.
A patchy, hit-and-miss comedy with a few outrageous highs and a lot of just-okay padding, Brüno suggests that Sacha Baron Cohen's in-your-face fool routine sadly isn't working any more.
A splendid study of the forces and passions behind the world's biggest fashion magazine.
This clever, surreal comedy is closer to the more whimsical work of a young Woody Allen.
A decent, well-cast and mounted adaptation that hits all the right notes but plays them in a respectful, muted monotone.

The fight scenes are deadpan and electric, as they should be in a Statham film, but the attempts at comedy and pathos are sorely misjudged in a loose-knit storyline that simply ambles to an underwhelming conclusion.
An often brilliant '50s-throwback character drama that never feels nostalgic, with terrific central performances and a luminous, unforgettable visual beauty.
What we hear is shocking enough; thankfully Oppenheimer leaves most of these savage horrors to our imagination.
Roth and Reeves lock us in for an increasingly terrifying thrillride.
The Overnight really belongs to the weirdly adorable Schwartzman, who literally lets it all hang out as the absurdly well-endowed Kurt.
A documentary that simply draws a picture of an organisation that is wealthy, secretive and controlling, a narrative that has been dominant for years.
movie_title: Going Clear: Scientology and the Prison of Belief (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Don't get too caught up in the all-too-familiar plot, just savour Jake Gyllenhaal's powerhouse performance in a riches-to-rags-to-redemption sports movie that punches well above its weight.
There may be no prizes for guessing how things turn out for Hope, but the role certainly allows its star to triumph.
Not all the songs work, but when they do they chill the spine and reinforce the mood of this powerful story about ordinary people who no longer wish to live with darkness.
Moselle has crafted the cinematic equivalent of a pencil sketch, but the boys make compelling viewing as her thoughtful, engaging subjects.
The stakes are high, but Dope is far from grim: it's a fast, funky and good-hearted take on the urban heist movie.
Woody Allen's films not only split into one of two genres these days - funny or not funny - they've also begun to repeat the tropes and themes of earlier, more successful efforts.
[A] visceral and savagely compelling action drama.
Hardy perfectly rations the in-jokes and suspense, building to a gooey and unnerving crescendo that recalls the heyday of the fright-flick.
Vikander is sensational in that rarest of things: a love story about a woman who finds her inner strength while letting go.
Tarantino has returned to his first film's template - colourful characters, a single room, blood and betrayal - but this time in a framework that is deliberately designed for repeat viewing.
Hardy does an admirable job of making this monster human, which he achieves with surprising wit and a visceral, attention-grabbing passion.
[Charlie's Country] not only captures some of the sad realities of today but also tells a poignant and universal story of a man struggling to come to terms with his place in a changing society.

Some typical Britfilm flourishes are present and correct - moody shots of the Goob whipping through the long grass, brandishing a stick - but the Norfolk setting, its sincere leads and an affecting score keep things a touch above the usual.
An exotic and satisfying alternative to the average Hollywood punch-'em-up, an offbeat war story with a neat sideline in ancient magic-realist philosophy.
The late-midlife crisis of a fading Hollywood star is the basis of this surprisingly profound and extraordinarily kinetic satire about life and success in the age of social media.

Tapping the formula that worked so well for The Full Monty and Billy Elliot, Pride adds some feel-good moments of its own in a broad, light and characterful romp that smuggles in some powerful, serious points about unity and togetherness.

Other actors would have milked the dramatic opportunities here for all they were worth, but Nixon and Abbott - the latter glimpsed briefly in A Most Violent Year - keep their sights on the heartbreaking inevitability of the situation.
It was first conceived as an art project, and is perhaps best viewed that way.
The film's subtle, underlying air of menace is nicely sustained throughout.
An unlikely mix of true-life tragedy and urban myth inspired this sweet, melancholy comedy ...
The quiz show conceit is never really used to its full potential, and the gangster subplot is just too dark for a film that aims to bowl you out on a fairytale high.
Superbly acted allegorical drama with a climax that is not only breathtakingly exciting but flawlessly handled.
Just when it seemed that there would never be another original teen horror movie comes this rough-edged but pleasingly creepy American indie ...
It borders on pretentious but never is, thanks largely to Dorval's wonderful, authentic performance as the titular everywoman.
[An] intelligent and surprisingly sensitive meditation on the way our society and its various media react to violent crime.
Although this ingenious sci-fi horror hybrid never quite delivers a story as dazzling as its visuals, its ambitions set it apart in an age of carbon-copy superhero movies.
Couples, be warned: this isn't date-night material.
Some may find the ending more cryptic than understated, but for those who embrace it, Glassland is a haunting study of the damage done by personal demons and desperation.
Neatly balances a folkloric coming-of-age tale with violent action thrills.
Sparks fly, but the grim cynicism of modern politics adds subversive weight to the film's screwball comedy stylings and has a lot to say about modern politics, in the US as well as abroad.
Episodic scenes of violence ensue but fans of martial arts should bed in for something more slow, spare and mysterious than the likes of Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon.
Bullock's usual audience might be turned off by her character's dark cynicism, but as meaty political satire this stands tall in a near-empty field.
Caine makes hay with a soulful role that brings his playful, world-weary charm to the fore, sparking quietly with Keitel, who gives generous, easy-going support.

Garfield, previously so passive, proves a surprisingly viable hero in all this mayhem, performing breathtaking acts of courage that one instinctively knows must pale next to the horrors of the real thing.
Mungiu paints an unflattering portrait of a society gone to seed, but the film's moral is universal: no matter how high-minded or well intended, corruption is always corruption.
Though it stays pleasingly light, using a beautifully balanced cast of old stalwarts and rising stars, Scherfig's film never sugarcoats the issues.

Coppola's most traditional film to date is a heightened, darkly comic, sexually tense drama that flips the male gaze, to show what happens when a man, for once, gets caught in the crosshairs of desire.
Falls just that little bit short, setting the bulk of his film work aside and leaving Lynch, by and large, unchallenged.
Often laugh-out-loud funny, bravely fencing with interracial tensions in post-9/11 America.
It reveals just how much more urgent the situation is, as global warming results in ever more extreme weather events.
movie_title: An Inconvenient Sequel: Truth To Power (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The legend of Jack the Ripper still looms heavy, but the spectre of his possible predecessor, an even more violent and capricious murderer active in London's East End, haunts this entertaining penny dreadful-style thriller.
Mannered and almost puppet-like in the lead, Farrell is a soulful and earnestly engaging presence, but Keoghan is the face to watch, as he slowly peels off the mask of sanity.
movie_title: The Killing of a Sacred Deer (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A terrific cast, which also includes Emma Thompson as Harold's fourth and current wife, adds needed warmth to the slightly chilly, Bergman-esque histrionics.

Darkest Hour is one of the better examples of the British prestige pic, an absorbing study of an over-mythologised political figure that depicts him not so much as a hero as a principled man snatching victory from the jaws of defeat.
Beirut proves surprisingly sensitive in its handling of the Middle East, mapping out an area of nuanced power struggle rather than a cartoon Casablanca-style warzone.
It's juicy, inspiring and empowering stuff; it's only a shame that such an intriguing and well-intentioned story couldn't have been told a little more adventurously.
Nothing in the story really sticks; amid endless iterations of AA meetings ... it's left to Callahan's scabrous cartoons to remind us just how dark his humour was.
movie_title: Don't Worry, He Won't Get Far on Foot (2018)

movie_review_blurb: It has its moments ... but Riley's vision needs a little more refining.
Though there are shades of Slumdog Millionaire in its gripping depiction of a young boy thrown by fate onto the streets of India, this affecting true story still has plenty to offer.
Redmayne handles all the stages of Hawking's terrible disease with great tact, always careful to portray the man and not the illness.
Affleck is on electrifying form as Lee, a surly janitor living alone in a Boston suburb.
A powerful and unsettling journey.
[The] climax ... ought to be powerful and ironic yet simply falls flat - a crushing damp squib of an ending for a film that begins with a tone of anarchic, irreverent promise.
There are flashes of what made the story interesting in the first place, not so much in the David v Goliath aspect of Omalu's work but in his fascinating approach to forensics.
First-time director Stephen Fingleton grippingly ramps up the tension as supplies dwindle and loyalties are tested.

Where others would simply concern itself with the mystery - who's really crazy here, and why? - directors Franz and Fiala are more interested in the human psychology, reflected in a creepily serene coda.
The final explosion into violence seems too pat in what is otherwise slick, sophisticated storytelling.
An intense, immersive experience that harrowingly but respectfully explores the personal and public horrors of the Holocaust.
The tension is slow-building but palpable, and the movie ends with a nail-biting home invasion and a refreshing feminist sting.
The film really doesn't have much more to say on the subject of male one-upmanship. Or much else, for that matter.
In other hands, this could easily be a pious period piece, but this isn't the story of a social experiment gone wrong.
The set-up is light and fun. LA is made luminous by Vittorio Storaro's magnificent camerawork. The plot, however, mostly treads water ...
It's a familiar story but one very well told, skewed by dry detail and snappy dialogue, scoring three top-notch performances with a great dustbowl soundtrack by Warren Ellis and Nick Cave.
Viggo Mortensen leads the charge in a spirited road movie about a family of social justice warriors from actor-turned-writer/director Matt Ross.
Although lightweight and silly with the best sight gag in recent memory, War On Everyone, for all its bile, strikes a surprisingly feel-good chord. Fun for all the delinquent, rainbow family.

Despite the arty flourishes and repetitions, this is a heady, intoxicating experience, interspersing the blurry hedonism of youth with jarring, sharply etched vignettes that remind us just how beautifully this director works with actors.
I, Daniel Blake is a small film about unheard voices that punches above its weight, made all the more relevant in the wake of the EU referendum.
One of the most brutal and intelligent nerve-jangling thrillers of 2016.

The way enmities quickly escalate is a little bit of a stretch, but otherwise this is a smartly handled, old-school adventure, as Law's beleaguered captain struggles to keep control both of his men and his wayward, leaking vessel.
It threads together the many story-lines, some of which you want to see more than others.
A terrific, sophisticated comedy that tackles serious issues with a lightness of touch and a spirit of steel, Philomena is the British film to beat come BAFTA time.
This is a film that makes some very interesting points about how society and the media can combine to create history's monsters.

Like all good horror stories Mickle's film is really about something else, and the two female leads give terrific performances as cloistered teenagers struggling to come to terms with their place in their world.
The fly on this particular wall comes with his own baggy threads and Madchester t-shirts, but the results are no less magical for being shot through the eyes of a fan.
movie_title: The Stone Roses: Made of Stone (2013)

movie_review_blurb: There's not enough of a story to sustain The Comedian through its frequent lulls, but its lush cinematic style suggests Shkolnik is one to watch.
Feels a little long and uneven, although Mortensen is quite superb as the two chalk-and-cheese brothers.
What lasts longest in the mind is not the film's bold gay love scenes but its affectionate tip of the hat to a great, unapologetic American eccentric.
What makes it at all special is Shannon, who's terrific playing the human being behind the murderer, a man so psychopathic that he doesn't realise he's actually a monster posing as a man.
Experimental and uncompromising, Winding Refn and Gosling's Drive follow-up is a tripped-out riff on the crime family movie in which The Grifters - literally - go to hell.
A VIP tour of a secret, horribly fashionable world that one wouldn't want to linger in yet can't help but find fascinating.
The film's limitations play to its advantage, since Ridley eschews the usual biopic approach, instead taking a snapshot of 12 crucial months in the musician's life, three years before his death.
movie_title: Jimi: All Is by My Side (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Brit filmmaker Sean Ellis does terrific work balancing the disparate elements of his crime-laced drama. Recommended.
The male-dominated world of voiceover artists is explored from a female perspective in this touching comedy from Lake Bell, who stars, writes and directs.
The enduring appeal of Jane Austen's England is explored in this uneven but often hilarious romp - a comedy, for once, aimed squarely at a female audience.
A bulked-up James McAvoy dominates the screen in this razor-sharp Glasgow smile of a black comedy, packed with aberrant sex, hard drugs and maximum David Soul.
Gordon Green follows up a pair of execrable comedies with a wise and witty slow-motion road trip that catches the sun.
Ahmed excels and the set-up is compelling but ultimately this is middle rank stuff from the Monsoon Wedding director.
A rousing tale of rock 'n' roll rebellion that shows how one man's black-vinyl passions ended up socking it to The Man.
A punchy and effective drama.
Laurence in particular is dynamic as Norris's young muse, a guileless screen presence who effortlessly charms us back to childhood.
Jennifer Lawrence is the standout in a tonally uneven, eccentric romantic dramedy that fuses The Fisher King with Romy And Michele's High School Reunion.
A timely and intelligent reminder of the dangers of public hysteria.
Huston, as ever, does the devil's work to perfection, but, with no one to like - let alone root for - this soon becomes a very long and tiresome slog indeed.
An endearingly oddball indie sci-fi.
Kill Your Darlings may be best described as an intellectual moral maze, a story perfectly of its time and yet one that still resonates today.

It is smart and surprisingly literate, its only downfall being in that, in riffing on the work of a very talented writer on the subject of men and women, its screenplay could have used a little more of Jane Austen's immaculate sense of storytelling.
Admirers of the first two films will feel pangs of nostalgia and a residual warmth for its charismatic leads, but as an extension to the series it feels forced and unnecessary.
Roger Michell's film contains frequent nods to the French nouvelle vague (notably Jean-Luc Godard's Bande à Part), while Hanif Kureishi's screenplay may be a trifle bookish and spiky for some tastes.
It may be divisive, but Two Mothers is a vary rare exploration of the female psyche, which, with a little judicious editing, could have a long and interesting life.
When the credits roll, one is left thinking less of the fate of the characters than of the rollcall of Sundance offerings this film resembles.
It is poetic, honest and at times almost upsettingly real. It will be fascinating to see what Ellis does next.

The acting isn't perfect (which is perhaps understandable under the circumstances), and the film's dream states sometimes try too hard, but Escape From Tomorrow has an otherworldly atmosphere that both hooks and engages.
[It] will likely find favour with horror audiences looking for something more thoughtful than another instalment of Saw.
Somewhere out there is a Royal Variety show missing its line-up.
A gripping, violent film that owes an unabashed debt to the Tarantino-penned love-in-low-places story True Romance.
Forget the sci-fi trimmings and sentimental pay-off - this is a gleefully subversive character study of a charming but unapologetic rogue.
Though Rob Epstein and Jeffrey Friedman's handsomely mounted period piece evokes the era with impressive detail, Lovelace's journey remains difficult to tell.
Talky it may be, but the acting is sublime, with director Nuri Bilge Ceylan able to contrast staggering, almost alien landscapes with scenes as intimate as anything on the West End stage.
Beautiful, funny, timely and tender, this is the American arthouse movie of the year.
A charming road movie that develops into a full-blown study of life and roots, offering a beautiful insight into the way families migrate and change.
Stevens is a charismatic antihero and the film plays expertly with genre expectations, leading to an inspired showdown in a haunted house prepared for a high-school dance.
A likeable, if predictable, black comedy that feels like a Tarantino movie made by well-meaning committee.
The personal awakening story is enjoyable and self-deprecatingly honest ...
Cahill's second feature film is another smart, inventive and engaging offering.
An unusual, science-based metaphysical thriller that manages to be both provocative and romantic.
Just as the zombie genre refuses to die, this fitfully funny and well cast black comedy doesn't know when to stop either.
Chazelle's terrific film takes us into the minds of two men searching for perfection.
A great cast and promising premise get swamped in an awkward mix of airport-novel noir and blokey family melodrama.
It bodes well for Downey's post-Iron Man future, but, sadly, the promised sparks never fly.
The black comedy is delicious, though the more violent set pieces are not for the faint of heart.
A surprisingly thoughtful meditation on the key year that transformed guitarist Jimi Hendrix (played by OutKast's André Benjamin) from session player to superstar.
movie_title: Jimi: All Is by My Side (2014)

movie_review_blurb: The culture clash between the average middle American and the rest of the world is used to entertaining effect in this kinetic crime thriller.
The nightmares that Bloom is selling are immaterial; what terrifies more is the cut-throat corporate culture that so willingly pays him - and pats him on the back.
Unlikely as it sounds, there's a refreshing innocence and intimacy to this pairing that really charms, and will work for female audiences in particular.
The tone is uneven, and the end a little queasy, but The Drop's unusual chemistry keeps the minimal plot ticking over nicely.
The humour here is dark and incisive, with an especially bold turn by Wright, who bears the brunt of some very harsh dialogue.
A vibrant, insightful film about writers and writing, featuring Daniel Radcliffe's best post-Potter performance.
A fitfully amusing Our Town that struggles to come to any kind of meaningful conclusion.
Binoche is excellent in a part that trades not on her beauty but her mind, portraying a woman whose talent made her dangerous in less enlightened times.
Bullock's almost balletic performance imbues this vertiginous fantasy with a humanity and grace that beautifully complements director Alfonso Cuarón's breathtaking vision.
It's a long and uncomfortable journey, but The Act of Killing is also fascinating, using film as a hall of mirrors to reveal not just the faces, but the twisted souls, of murderers.
Scorsese's funniest and most focused film in a long time, a jet-black sex and drug-soaked comedy featuring a bravura performance by Leonardo DiCaprio.
[A] polished biographical drama ...
Morgan Freeman is impressive as Dunn's crumpled sidekick, and Oscar winner Swank is terrific, too, but this is Clint's film, both as its tortured hero and as a great American director.
This is an exhilarating story of decadence and debauchery, made all the more thrilling by DiCaprio's charismatic and physical lead performance.
Not much happens, and its roots as an improvised project do show through, but the film does have the authentic ring of carefree wanderlust about it.
For an hour, the film borders on genius, with playful visuals and unbelievable in-camera effects ...
The music choices alone will ensure this haunting, beautifully detailed film will live a long and lasting life.
A brutal, immersive prison survival story with a breakout performance by British actor Jack O'Connell.
Though it is more ambitious in scope, The Raid 2 remains, primarily, a visceral pulp action movie, and this is where it truly soars.
A very welcome return from Moodysson. The music is Wyld Stallions-grade, but the charm and spirit of the three girls will have you moshing in your seat.
Dreams of rock stardom become a warped reality in this barking-mad but affecting comedy about the side-effects of being a non-conformist genius.
A familiarity with baseball is probably crucial to getting the most out of this quiet, absorbing drama.

It's hard to imagine the true story of Britain's first mixed-race aristocrat being told more elegantly than in this warm and often very funny period piece, which brings a subtle political gravitas to its central fairy-tale romance.
Another meticulously stylish and deadpan Wes Anderson movie that walks the fine line between masterpiece and folly.
This is an absolute crowd-pleaser that will have you laughing harder than most studio comedies.
Relentlessly bleak from the first frame, this final outing pulls no punches as white knuckle action sequences see the casualty rate rise alongside the tension.
Worthington and Oxenbould strike up a believable father/son dynamic, meaning that you can't help but smile at the inevitably schmaltzy ending.
If you're still young enough to see in the sunrise on a cocktail of pills, booze and delirium - or old enough to have survived a few - this is one party you'll wish you'd been at.
It is, as such, a very British tale and a contender for football film of the decade.

Fiendishly plotted and with awesomely kinetic (and outrageously bloody) action scenes, Blomkamp announces himself in a major way, without letting the third act crescendo lose focus in a blur of noise.
Soderbergh proves he's still got the lightness of touch that marked him out as one to watch 20 years ago with Sex, Lies and Videotape.

The Gallic gangster tradition appears to be in rude health. Audiard's film is a triumph that deserves international recognition, but as with the likes of Gomorrah, films that tell it like it is reap their own rewards.
Angels with machine guns? It was probably great fun to make; just don't expect to have quite as good a time watching it. As a piece of action horror it suffers from an identity crisis.
Like all films that strike a chord, you'll find yourself replaying your own memories as the credits roll on a comedy that fires the heart.
A fresh approach to the relationship comedy that will reward repeat viewings.
Please don't quit, Kev. We've forgiven you for Jersey Girl. Honest.
A rare glimpse into the mind of the gonzo writer and among Depp's best work.
Underpinned by a surprisingly touching rom-com sub plot twinning Doug with Scott Pilgrim's Alison Pill, Goon is pucking funny stuff.
Above all it's just plain fun, and the songs are catchy, too.

Breakfast of Champions -- the movie -- isn't the book, but it's probably the best screen adaptation Alan Rudolph or any other director could hope to get out of the source material.
Jeff Nichols sets out to emulate Spielberg, and ends up with his own distinct sci-fi film.
Sure, Drake Burnette's Marfa Girl looks real. But like the rest of the film, she doesn't feel real.

What separates Animals from its twitchier brethren is a keen sense of place.
As hard as Pet tries to be something different, it still feels like a film about a woman in a dog cage.
John Carchietta nails the more subtle, painful aspects of teenhood. That's a harder thing to pull off than a grindhouse flick, which makes Teenage Cocktail an impressive, if slightly uneven, debut.
Operation Avalanche isn't just about the thrill of making movies - it's about the thrill of making history.
The Wrecking Crew isn't about something falling apart, but a specific moment in time: a time that, as a viewer, you keep wanting to revisit.
The most compelling sections of Miss Sharon Jones are still her leaps in physical and creative strength. As Kopple and Jones prove, the struggle itself can be just as inspiring as survival.
The whole thing becomes equivalent to watching a video game, only without the fun of actually getting to play it.
As much as the moviegoer in you might prefer the animation to be carried to the very end, Maitland reminds us that, style aside, Tower is a story that's all too real.

Gerald's Game was never going to be the easiest Stephen King novel to bring to the big screen, and despite a handful of faults, it's that rare horror film that works on both a psychological and a visceral level.
Zak Hilditch - like Gerald's Game director Mike Flanagan - knows that, even with the pathos behind it, this is still a horror story.
Burnham thankfully never loses sight of the belief that things truly can get better if you want them to.
At a certain point, though, Ready Player One wants to be appreciated as a film as well as a movie, no matter what Spielberg says. And that's where it begins to falter.

Torn Curtain is not a total disaster.
It's a movie that's haunted by death, with lengthy sequences played out in cemeteries.
This is just another male menopause movie, marred by unlikely dialogue and hokey theatrical symbolism.
A provocative, if minor, Demy film.
Ham-fisted, maddeningly overwritten, and about as subtle as a jackhammer.
Stiller's direction is only adequate most of the time, and there are a lot of mismatched eyelines and shots that feel off-balance and uncertain.
This threadbare little thriller looks like it was written and shot over a weekend.
Every magic hour, light-drenched image in Victor Erice's Spirit of the Beehive is filled with mysterious dread.

The prolific Johnny To and his occasional collaborator Wai Ka Fai here put a new twist on the standard police yarn.

Though Schutte doesn't quite rise to the challenge, he is greatly helped by the presence of veteran Viennese stage actor Otto Tausig, who inhabits the character of Max Kohn as if were been born into it.
This feels like the work of an octogenarian who wishes to be leave those close to her a well rounded self-portrait to remember her by.

movie_review_blurb: Kornel Mundruczo is back on his feet with his best rounded and most mature work to date.

movie_title: La Fille de Monaco (The Girl from Monaco) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: To Palfi's credit, he never attempts to titillate. His mind-boggling visual imagination is ably supported by Gergely Poharnok's camera and the art direction.

movie_review_blurb: Discreet, old-fashioned, traditional and altogether admirable, this is Jan Troell at his best.

movie_review_blurb: A lively, dense and richly imaginative portrait not only of a great writer but also of the post-Second World War cultural world of the Soviet Union.

movie_title: GETT: The Trial of Viviane Amsalem (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Taking a break from his regular diet of fantasy and horror, Japan's Kiyoshi Kurosawa delivers here a fierce indictment of modern-day Japan.

Chemla is a perfect choice for the lead, whether she is exuding happy expectancy from life as a young girl, stubbornly standing by her hopelessly spoiled brat when she shouldn't, or gradually losing her mind towards the end.

[An] earnest but overstated social drama whose real point of interest and its most interesting part remains the authentic case on which it is based.

movie_title: The Other Side of Hope (Toivon tuolla puolen) (2017)

A delightful surprise ...

[The film] has very little that is original or perceptive to say on a subject that needs far more incisive treatment.

One of Tarkovsky's most impenetrable films, it nonetheless left me staggered and awestruck.

So truthful, so prescient, it's painful. Paddy Chayevsky delivers one of the best screenplays ever written.
Lean, Mean and On Point. Stone's best film.

Simultaneously and paradoxically irreverent and loving. A terrific piece of cinematic entertainment

A film I'll be able to return in years hence and have lovely waves of happiness wash over me.

a beautiful film about sickness, a funny film about degeneracy

characters simply don't have anything particularly interesting to say to each other or do together

Dreadful, witless and pointless.

the film will be remembered for the overall sense of camaraderie overcoming competition, fraternity trumping rivalry, and the discovery of graciousness in victory and defeat

Longley is a strikingly effective director
Norm McLaren one of the greatest artists ever to work within Canadian borders
Royal Tenenbaums meets Malcolm in the Middle. Oh, and let's not forget Weekend at Bernie's.
An interesting if not entirely satisfactory theatrical interpretation of magical rivalries.
Fine performances all around in this admirable, if not exactly great, film.
An amazing achievement for a 'first-time' filmmaker, which measures up to the finest indies for performance and character-work, and the biggest blockbusters for jaw-dropping effects.
Not as deep as the original, but certainly more of a crowdpleaser -- and it's hard to imagine a more intelligent and well-crafted American horror being released this year.
A kids' movie for grown-ups. A grown-up movie for kids. Exactly what you'd expect -- and hope for -- from the latest, and we're guessing final, Woody and Buzz adventure.

An encouraging set-up soon descends into a grubby muddle, leaving you wishing you were just rewatching The Name Of The Rose instead.
Tells the story of comedian Bill Hicks' tragically short life through the eyes of those who lived it with him.
Grown-up but not too serious; action-packed but not juvenile.
A gritty, brutal chase movie that's more about swords (and spears, and axes) than sandals -- although it could have done with a lot more character-meat on those bones.
Aside from a few neat flourishes, this is attention-sapping stuff, lacking texture in both its visuals and vocal performances.
Good central performances in this highly, entertaining character-driven debut.
Not exactly genre-bending innovation or anything but a decent documentary about an important episode in history of oil company exploitation.
One of the most chillingly effective visions of the world's end ever put on screen - and a heart-rending study of parenthood, to boot.
A film for anyone who's ever climbed trees, grazed knees or basked in the comfort of a parent's sympathy as they've pulled you off the ground crying. It'll make your inner child run wild.
A decent but unremarkable film with a big, unforgettable central performance. Carey Mulligan passes with First-Class Honours.
The action is enthralling even if the storyline doesn't always have the ring of truth about it.
Intelligent and uncompromising, with knock-out performances from Downey Jr. and Foxx.
Bond without the style and Team America without the bellylaughs. The moronic script and nonsensical plot are good for a snicker, though.
movie_title: G.I. Joe: The Rise of Cobra (2009)
