Admirably low-key, deeply compelling and their warmest movie since Fargo.
It hardly rewrites the rulebook, but Warrior is a powerful, moving and brilliant sports-pic-cum-family drama. Like The Fighter, but with kicking.
A beautifully realised adaptation of a profoundly affecting novel.
An honest, affection-hooking, coming-of-age drama which proves that there is life beyond Hogwarts for Emma Watson.
movie_title: The Perks of Being a Wallflower (2012)

movie_review_blurb: An odd one. Rogen's latest clown is an angry, confused man who you never feel entirely comfortable laughing at. There are laughs - you'll just feel guilty afterwards...
A great concert movie framed around a substantially less enthralling interview.
movie_title: Shut Up and Play the Hits (2012)

movie_review_blurb: As beige as an old PC, but beneath the surface the blood pumps bright scarlet. An intelligent and emotionally charged spy drama.
The grave tone makes it stiff and leaden, the digi-saturated look is a turn-off. Damnable and disordered.
A strong visual style tussles with flaccid storytelling in this ambitious retelling of Grimm.
The closest Mel Gibson's come to playing Martin Riggs since the last Lethal Weapon.
For horror hounds who love a larf, and those of us who always wondered exactly what that dry-ice stuff that rises out of the forest-floor moss is.
Just about every sci-fi/fantasy/superhero adventure you ever loved is in here somewhere.
A familiar story oddly presented, but with a powerful central performance from Woody Harrelson.
An extraordinary, intoxicating movie. Its hard, twisted edges may turn off some, but there's no faulting either Aronofsky's technical mastery or Portman's flawless performance.
A marvellous follow-up to 2004's Sideways - well worth the wait.
A starkly effective ensemble drama which could well do for the sniffles what Jaws did for great whites.
Stupid, with three o's. But also fun, never boring, and never insulting (to anyone other than Dumas) - unlike certain of the summer's A-pics...
A simple entertainment in a summer of overcomplicated disappointments. Also much harder-edged than you may have expected.
Gripping, heart-wrenching, powerful and a sad indictment of scientific practice, which shows that 'human' and 'humane' are all-too-often mutually exclusive.
A beautifully crafted, intimate adventure movie and - presented in hand-drawn 2D - one of the most visually arresting you'll enjoy all year.
A worthy paean to a true talent.

All you'd expect from an X-Men film (or spin-off, or prequel), but not all you'd hope for. It smacks of rush and compromise, but there's thankfully enough to make you feel optimistic about the series' future once more.
Ambitious and visually impressive as a pop-video mash-up, but, lacking a strong emotional core, it doesn't quite cohere as a fully satisfying movie.
A perfect blend of cool, quirky comedy and warm-hearted drama, crafted with such poise that it should see the transcendence of Ayoade from TV nerd-comic to true big-screen talent.
Still no signs of the master re-living past glories, but more than worthwhile for Allen diehards.
movie_title: You Will Meet a Tall Dark Stranger (2010)

movie_review_blurb: One of Streep's finest-ever performances.
It's intriguing and challenging, although Castro's Raúl never quite comes to full-blooded life, remaining a brittle vessel for the points Larrain seeks to score.
A twist-burdened techno-thriller that would be by-the-numbers if it could count.
A tangled narrative and damp-squib ending detract from an otherwise joyous Spaghetti Eastern.
movie_title: The Good, the Bad, the Weird (Joheun-nom, Nabbeun-nom, Isanghan-nom) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Odd, but brilliantly so. It's a small film that feels big, a period drama that looks modern, defying comparison to anything but Nolan himself.
The odd conclusion renders it somewhat oblique, but Perfume is a feast for the senses. Smell it with your eyes...
movie_title: Perfume: The Story of a Murderer (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Impossible to recommend as a great Friday night out, yet agonisingly vital as thought-urging cinema.
Absurd, outrageous, gross, disturbing, insightful, and so funny it'll burst half the blood vessels in your face.
movie_title: Borat: Cultural Learnings of America for Make Benefit Glorious Nation of Kazakhstan (2006)

movie_review_blurb: On the Ferrellometer, Talladega Nights sits just above Kicking & Screaming, when it should be redlining it up there with Anchorman.
movie_title: Talladega Nights: The Ballad of Ricky Bobby (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Thankfully, the bits that matter most -- the dust-ups -- are superb.
Too long, and too wrapped up in its various plot contrivances to notice it's veering off course. But Jack just about pulls the wheel back, aided by Verbinski's flair for cartoonish comedy action.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Man's Chest (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Structural scrappiness aside, it remains a laudably amoral and superbly caustic comedy for those who like their satire strong and unfiltered.

Singer's absence is felt but not fatal. By adding too much new blood Ratner loses some of the original DNA, but with its nifty set-pieces and a few nasty surprises, X3's still a worthy enough sequel to ensure it's no Last Stand.
An amiable enough micro-caper which offers savoury titters over out-and-out laughs without ever living up to the concept's comedic potential.
A sharper account of the Iwo Jima conflict than Flags, this balances its unflinching handling of the horrors of war with its touching portrayal of those who face them.
Brilliantly observed characters are becoming second nature to Payne and Taylor, and the performances here are uniformly terrific. This is wonderful, original stuff.
Twisted, mysterious, bold and compelling, this is a raging cyclone of a movie, sucking up elements from the likes of Blade and The Matrix and whirling them into something new.
Who cares about overdone orchestral blasts or signpost-waving lines of dialogue when such raw, naked, painful humanity is displayed by Don Cheadle in the central role?
Part punk wildlife doc, part diary of a twisted soul, part cautionary tale, Grizzly Man is a complex, unique and engrossing journey into the murky recesses of an unhinged mind.
What could have been Jackson's folly is a triumph, the kind of romantic action spectacle that makes the big screen silver and provides box-office gold. Puts the prime in primate.
Setting out more to challenge us with its ideas than make us whoop at the action, Vendetta can be clumsy, but there are enough impressive flourishes to make up for its stumblings.
It's a cold, brittle film, capable of grabbing attention but unable to emotionally absorb.
Interesting and unsettling, but never terrifying.
Brutal, bloody, terrifying, astonishing.
As it dawns on the couple that they've slipped several links down the food chain, you're right there with them.

The Hobbit plays younger and lighter than Fellowship and its follow-ups, but does right by the faithful and has a strength in Martin Freeman's Bilbo that may yet see this trilogy measure up to the last one. There is treasure here.
If you're up for it, you'll discover a fresh, funny little romp unafraid to tackle the biggest issues of all.
Think Donnie Brasco, with the IRA instead of the Mafia. Jim Sturgess dominates with a star-making turn, although some stylistic slip-ups let him down a little.
A war film more of sober, grim reflection than balls-out escapades. Yet it grips consistently, its bursts of combat delivering gut-punches of veracity.
Plenty of over-British Britishness in this predictable drama.
A film more concerned with 'how' than 'why' or 'who', Valkyrie would have benefited from more scrutiny and complexity. Still, once the bomb goes off, the thrills come in spades.
An emotional smackdown. Rourke's never been better, and the change of pace and texture suits Aronofsky perfectly. The Raging Bull of wrestling movies? Oh, go on then.

Kenan's palpable affection for his central creation is so strong that once we're gasping fresh air, we want to dive back in, get to know Ember's intriguing denizens better and properly explore its claustrophobic hinterland. Something we're sadly denied.
If you took Commando and replaced all its humour (intentional or otherwise) with snarling hatred, you'd end up with Taken - a risible male-re-empowerment fantasy.
There are moments of comedy grandeur, but this isn't as consistently funny as you'd hope. Nevertheless, Downey Jr.'s Kirk Lazarus is instantly up there with the comedy greats.
Nic Balthazar's morality tale is a shrewd exercise in expectation-subversion.
A film so numbingly unamusing that you seriously question whether you were mistaken to have ever found Myers funny.
Astonishing, unforgettable: you have to see it.
Unscary, uninteresting tosh from people who should know better.

It's not sure where to go once the final Iron Man suit is constructed, and seems in a rush to get there, but Downey Jr and the supporting cast are so perfectly placed we're already looking forward to the bound-to-be-better sequel.
Deeply impressive, as both a recreation of â(TM)80s working-class England and an intimate tale of one childhoodâ(TM)s brutal end.
Terrible, just terrible.
movie_title: Captain Eager and the Mark of Voth (2008)

movie_review_blurb: A potentially disposable, tongue-in-cheek First Blood pisstake turns out to be a deeply effective, surprisingly touching tale of family and childhood friendship. If you only see one Rambo movie this year, make sure it's this one.
All the boys might love Mandy Lane -- discerning horror fans, however, will not.
movie_title: All the Boys Love Mandy Lane (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Targeted at pre-schoolers yet with scant educational value, Arctic Tale is best seen by no-one.
An engaging melodrama whose less convincing plot points are superseded by some astonishingly affecting performances from the mostly unknown cast.

While the sun shines, it's a four-star thriller with a superb turn from Smith. When the moon rises, it's a two-star horror cartoon with some of the worst FX we've seen all year. So, really, it has to average out at...
With the whole of America as his backdrop, Penn pulls off his most ambitious movie yet. The result is a beautiful and thought-provoking road movie.
Patchy but great fun, peppering plenty of black humour into a sweet if silly fairy-tale romance.
The year's most pleasant cinematic surprise. Once has enough heart, wit, verve and sheer songwriting genius to ensure you'll see it far more times than its title suggests.
A sharp and compelling war drama that delivers on the promise of its astonishing true-life origins.

Another summer threequel, another case of slipping standards - not so much in the visuals, which remain predictably impressive, but in the all-important gag rate. To waste both Donkey and Puss is a crime...
Mike Leigh draws a bravura performance out of Sally Hawkins, and she in return makes Poppy one of Leigh's best characters yet - up there with the likes of Vera Drake or Beverly from Abigail's Party.
Another strong, sparky and bloody entry in the QT canon.
For all its verve and creative enthusiasm, Spaceship's oblique and flighty nature leaves it feeling decidedly niche.
A confident, ambitious and action-rich Brit thriller, albeit one whose characters and clarity suffer from the frantic intensity of its pacing.
When it comes to playing a properly magnetic anti-hero with a gruff '70s-cinema exterior and a dark reservoir of inner depth, Jackman really is the best at what he does.
A genre-defying film. Its visual splendour belies its tough, surface-level subject matter, while the performances pull us deep below that surface with their soulful naturalism.
Loving soars thanks to its narrative approach and career-best performances from Negga and Edgerton.
We've seen all these stunts pulled before, and seen them done better, but there's some pleasure to be had here -- even if it's of the extremely guilty kind.
An engaging study of a beautiful but mysterious mind, which also reveals the stressful nature of world-class chess tournaments and raises the deep question of where intelligence actually comes from.
An astonishing true story that's treated with an admirably light and artistic touch, rather than an overly dramatic heavy hand.
A handsome period drama with the occasional impressive flourish, but despite its rich subject matter, it's Affleck's weakest film yet as a director.
Part fairy tale/creature feature/domestic melodrama, this adds up to far more than a 'one boy and his monster' story - and is a tougher emotional journey as a result.
It may be predictable, but Bleed For This still grabs with its astonishing against-all-odds true story, and its belter of a central performance from Miles Teller.
Part body-swap comedy, part long-distance romance, part... something else. If you only see one Japanese animated feature this year, see this one, and see it more than once.
A family/crime drama with shades of Shane Meadows' early work and a satisfying double act in Fassbender and Gleeson.
A lesser Werner, but still worth dipping your brain into.
movie_title: Lo and Behold, Reveries of the Connected World (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Too long, arduous, lecturey and patience-testing for even the all-new Matthew McConaughey to rescue.
A bit Up, a bit Moonrise Kingdom, a bit Midnight Run, even... Taika Waititi's latest is an oddball treat of a mismatched-buddy pursuit move.
Like Stories We Tell or Dig!, Tickled subverts your expectations. Definitely strange rather than ha-ha.
An otherwise mundane rom-com that doesn't know how to handle its one point-of-difference; and even that isn't as much of a big deal as its writers think it is.
movie_title: Up for Love (Un homme à la hauteur) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Like Avengers Assemble forced through a Deadpool mangle, Suicide Squad gives new life to DC's big-screen universe. So bad-to-the-bone it's good.
As spectacular as you'd hope from a sequel to the 1996 planet-toaster, and as amusingly cheesy. You'll enjoy yourself enough that you won't even miss Will Smith.
An intimate, emotional journey, which may lack the scope and scale of previous Ghibli adventures, but remains a bittersweet sayonara for the studio.
A lavish curio that at times tests your patience, but rewards you with its sumptuous design.
movie_title: Tale of Tales (Il racconto dei racconti) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: While the overall structure of his argument here is flimsy, the details he reveals have impact, suggesting a fair and just society is not an unattainable Utopia.
A lesser entry in the LeCarré Cinematic Universe, though Damian Lewis and Stellan Skarsgård rescue it from complete blandness.
Arrival is Villeneuve's The Day The Earth Stood Still or Close Encounters Of The Third Kind, and somehow he makes it true to the tropes while also feeling like something new.
Matching its blockbuster scale and spectacle with the smarts of a great, grown-up thriller, Captain America: Civil War is Marvel Studios' finest film yet.
Solid and stately, a '70s-feeling jungle adventure film that's more of a thought-provoker than an excitement-inducer. But there's nothing wrong with that.
Not the return to form you might have been hoping for. Its story might cover all the same beats as the 2003 original, but there's little of that film's spark or spirit.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Men Tell No Tales (2017)

movie_review_blurb: An interesting new take on a very well-known tale and a praiseworthy act of revisionism, but one which doesn't ultimately deliver on its early promise.
A raw, lean and abrasively effective thriller from Steven Soderbergh, which features Claire Foy as we've never seen her before.
Fans of Moon and Source Code be warned: Mute is sadly, almost tragically, not worth the wait.
Paul Thomas Anderson does gothic romance in prestige Brit picture style, eliciting a worthy final performance from Daniel Day-Lewis that's admirably matched by newcomer Vicky Krieps.
"I know it's hard, but act like you've seen it before," one character says to gawking young hero Thomas (Dylan O'Brien) on arrival. Not hard at all.
A finely crafted Western which doesn't flinch from portraying the horrors inflicted during that violent era, and which boasts an astounding performance from Christian Bale.
By turns amusing and harrowing, and with a compelling figure at its heart, The Prince Of Nothingwood proves how the show really can go on, no matter how terrible the circumstances.
A lightweight, tinselly film with some nice touches and appealing performances, though it never lands its darker moments.
Churchill's darkest hour is Gary Oldman's finest. Gripping, touching, amusing and enlightening, his performance is the prime reason this film must be seen - but not the only one.
It dives headlong into a scrappy, Swiss-cheese plot which, while true to DC Comics' mix-and-match mythology, clumsily slaps together its disparate elements.
So heavily derivative it doesn't feel like anything new, and there's little depth beneath that slick surface. But it's solid and attractive, at least, with a retro appeal to its cyberpunk stylings.
Psycho's accepted greatness means we can leave it on the shelf as we look for newer sensations. This prompts an urgent desire to revisit it.
A lurching misstep from the Dead Snow director.
As ultraviolent as the first film, and as ultrasmutty, The Golden Circle will leave the Kingsfans grinning, even if its characters have less growing to do this time around.
A sorta-sequel to Mrs Brown deals effectively with another of Queen Victoria's unconventional friendships and reprises Judi Dench's powerful and unparalleled portrayal.
Like all our most vivid bad dreams, it snags the mind. With barbs.
An affectionate but unflinching portrait of a family consumed by its dedication to Formula 1, thanks in main to its seemingly unstoppable patriarch, Sir Frank Williams.
A fiendishly effective holiday-gone-wrong thriller that's better at cranking up the agoraphobic action than fleshing out its characters.
A wildly ambitious space opera, but also a self-indulgent narrative morass. Sometimes, it seems, creativity can benefit from a few limitations.
movie_title: Valerian and the City of a Thousand Planets (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A gorgeously rendered and deeply personal portrayal of a young woman's life in the part of the world where history's greatest conflict reached a devastating conclusion.
movie_title: In This Corner of the World (Kono sekai no katasumi ni) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: An odd but frothily entertaining genre cocktail, which coasts on the charisma of its two biggest names and keeps things just fun enough to forgive its considerable lapses in narrative.
A lush and luminous visual symphony, which celebrates nature as both a furious, deadly force and a soothing source of love, this arthouse animation deserves to draw a big crowd.
Visually immaculate, swirling with themes as heart-rending as they are mind-twisting, 2049 is, without doubt, a good year. And one of 2017's best.
A largely inventive and energetic portrayal of a past-their-prime music legend that's let down by its unnecessary trad biopic beats.
A sufficiently engaging delve into a niche interest and those who feel defined by it. But one which, narratively at least, backs the wrong gamecock.
A middle-of-the-road drama populated by stock characters.

While Miyazaki's two-hour-long, historical-melodrama swansong is destined to be his most divisive film yet, it is also his most adult and interesting, and never less than visually breathtaking throughout.

It may climax with an overly formulaic splurge, but The Winter Soldier benefits from an old-school-thriller tone that, for its first half at least, distinguishes it from its more obviously superheroic Marvel cousins.
Inventive, ambitious, brutal and beautiful: a potent mythological epic. But also willfully challenging, as likely to infuriate as inspire.
A tender, nostalgic and warm 'family' drama which also quietly seethes with the threat and tension of imminent danger. Labor Day shows a new side to Jason Reitman as a filmmaker, and we like it.
Patchy and in need of a rigorous edit, but amid all the weeds there is some ripe comedy - satire, even - for the plucking.
It's fashionable to dismiss mumblecore as prone to obtuseness, but Bujalski offers a wryly funny slice of nerd-vana.
Bitty and frustrating, its bigger laughs are set against some off-balance storytelling and crude comedy. Not one to take your nan to.
Both Greengrass and Hanks are on award-deserving form in a riveting, emotionally complex and hugely intelligent dramatisation of a real-life ordeal.
Writer / director team Kureishi and Michell add to their partnership with an insightful look at a life-long commitment.
Violent, silly, embarrassing, clumsy, confusing, juvenile, occasionally offensive, occasionally a little bit fun.
A decent, cogent, greyly atmospheric thriller with something to say about War-On-Terror America.
Ruddy hilarious. Just what big-screen comedy needed.
Kormákur has made a suitably dramatic recreation of a remarkable episode.
Back on home turf, Contraband director Kormákur has made a suitably dramatic recreation of a remarkable episode.
Polley's fearless personal journey is a huge achievement, a genuine revelation - but the less detail you know beforehand, the better. Go in cold, come out warmed.
Following Made Of Stone, this is another slice of nostalgia for baggies of a certain age.
It feels the right Superman origin story for our era, and teases what would be a welcome new superfranchise.

An otherworldly tale of childhood and a definitive work of imagination.

A beautifully murky, hard-edged thriller. Quite simply, one of the best films of the year.

Unique, beautiful and endlessly fascinating. It really is a work of art.

It succeeds because it treats viewers to what television audiences didn't see when Billie Jean King and Bobby Riggs faced each other.

Cruise's Seal often tells his own story in American Made, but it's hard to know when he's on the level. Perhaps it's that difficulty that makes the tale so fascinating 30 years after he flew covert missions.
Crown Heights is based on an actual crime and genuinely appalling miscarriage of justice. Thankfully, it's also a story of friendship that's as uplifting as it is rightly upsetting.
The self-awareness is back with a vengeance in The Lego Ninjago Movie, but the story line is a few bricks shy of a play set.
Argentinean director Andy Muschietti is more concerned about sustaining dread than making sense.

To do justice to The Nut Job 2: Nutty by Nature, I'm going to follow the advice of Thumper the rabbit from another animated movie called Bambi. He counsels viewers, "If you can't say something nice, don't say nothing at all."
movie_title: The Nut Job 2: Nutty by Nature (2017)

movie_review_blurb: In her second movie on her own, Annabelle manages to imitate the pacing, the Catholic overtones and the tone of the first movie but replaces all the chills with unintentional laughter.
Rumble packs a lot of material and great sounds in its 103 minutes.
movie_title: RUMBLE: The Indians Who Rocked the World (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Leitch has worked as a stuntman, and he knows how to stage action. In Atomic Blonde, he finds in 1989 Berlin a nearly ideal environment for photogenic bloodshed.
Screenwriters Kenya Barris and Tracy Oliver seem to be following a gross-out comedy template, but the two come up with just enough naughty gags to make the familiar journey work.
What Nolan gets right in Dunkirk -- from the action to the spare dialogue -- is so good that it makes the fact that any narrative deficiencies exist seem all the more disappointing.
Wright assumes viewers are paying close attention and love obscure references and deep cuts. Thankfully, his obsessions are incurably contagious.

Watts effortlessly juggles classroom comedy with larger than life derring-do. Having Keaton for a villain really helps because his manic energy can be amusing and threatening -- depending on the context.
Just when it looked as if those goofy, bumbling Minions had lost their appeal, writers Cinco Paul and Ken Daurio have come up with just enough inspired silliness to merit another installment.
Sofia Coppola's take on Thomas Collinan's novel The Beguiled slowly but effortlessly glides from wishful thinking to the stuff of nightmares.
All of this might have been more fun if Bay had a sense of humor, but he has a moth-to-flame attraction to every corny aside imaginable.
Blanchett recites some of the texts as if she were a lonely voice in the wilderness, but much of Manifesto is side-splittingly funny.

If the setup is familiar (Gregg Hurwitz's script owes an enormous debt to Alfred Hitchcock's Rear Window), there are enough quirks in the tale to prevent viewers from feeling that they've gotten ahead of the boy genius.
In its final form, the new DC adventure reflects its challenging production, but it does come closer than some of predecessors to giving its iconic stable of characters justice.

My Cousin Rachel features terrific camera work from Mike Eley, and Michell certainly gets the tone and setting right. But the figures in the foreground seem to be competing against the cliffside scenery instead of occupying it.
If Petrov can be irritable, The Man Who Saved The World reveals he can just as easily be endearing.
movie_title: The Man Who Saved the World (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Considering the sordid themes running throughout Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri, McDonagh's tone is astonishingly warm. He knows how to poke fun at characters' quirks without demeaning them.
By making her quiet corner of the screen more captivating than the portions where people are yelling or screaming, it's easy to see how Rampling won Best Actress at the Venice Film Festival.
Einstein gets mentioned in A Wrinkle in Time, but he and the audience would be better served if the filmmakers had figured out how to present his thoughts instead of dropping his name.
Rookie feature director Sophie Brooks can get away with a few missteps in The Boy Downstairs because she understands one basic truth: Love turns rational, intelligent adults into blithering idiots.
Abacus moves at a brisk pace and never feels dry or procedural.
[Kate] Davis avoids making a shallow diatribe from its volatile subject.
Knife Skills is inspiring without being sappy.
McMillion Shelton doesn't sugarcoat the severity of the crisis, but watching these women addressing it is oddly hopeful and entertaining.
[Mindy Alper's] art, including the doodles she drew as a kid, is astonishingly sensitive, and Stiefel uses animation and optical effects to put viewers into Alper's head.
movie_title: Heaven Is a Traffic Jam On the 405 (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Edith + Eddie is tricky to get through, but it's as engrossing as it is heartbreaking.
It's a straightforward, if amusing, sketch, but Lawson and director Derin Seale sprinkle in just enough clues to reveal there might be something else at work.
[Rachel] Shenton is an advocate for the deaf, but she also gives Libby's parents just enough depth to explain why they aren't spending enough time with their daughter.
German director Katja Benrath effortlessly builds tension and honors Farah without having her film descending into a sermon.
[Dorian] Davis' commanding performance anchors the film, and he and [Joshua] Wright bear an uncanny resemblance to their real-life counterparts.
Writer-director Reed Van Dyk gives both actors remarkably meaty if not flashy roles and avoids the temptation for long monologues, which would kill any narrative tension.
Jakob Schub and Jan Lachauer have not only preserved Dahl's agile wordplay and amusingly macabre sensibilities, but they've also captured the look of the drawings Quentin Blake illustrated them with.
Victor Caire and Gabriel Grapperon have adopted a hyper-realistic style that makes it seem as if the hungry and later happy amphibians are devouring the previously forbidden delights.
It's a given that a Pixar movie is going to be entertaining and visually appealing, but directors Dave Mullins and Dina Murray also address playground bullying in a refreshing and amusing manner.
The impact of this film is like watching a long, slow fuse detonating in a spectacular fashion.
[Kobe] Bryant's narration and Keane's drawings (which look like Leroy Neiman paintings come to life) mesh beautifully. It's hard to imagine another farewell this touching.
Nonetheless, by stepping backward in filmmaking technology and content, he creates a story that might endure like a cave painting.
[Will] Gluck wisely prevents Thomas from becoming a one-sided villain, but his run-ins with the animals play like a warmed-over retelling of Home Alone.
Clara's Ghost is that rare movie that works despite the fact that its only grounded and likable character is a pot dealer.
Act & Punishment gets a little repetitive, but don't be surprised if you find yourself wanting to put on a ski mask and challenge authority.
But the Americans in 12 Strong are thinly realized, and it's hard to get emotionally involved in their fate even if they're in the most dangerous situation imaginable.

Saldanha knows children will eventually have to make the same difficult choices their parents have. It's an achievement that he has delightfully managed to address that fact with the help of a gentle, friendly bull.
Novitiate is a rare film about religion that neither bludgeons a viewer into accepting an ideology nor treats believers as misguided simpletons.
Jenkins delivers a superhero movie that's better than those helmed by her male predecessors who weren't Richard Donner or Christopher Nolan.

In adapting Dav Pilkey's children's books for the big screen, Captain Underpants director David Soren (Turbo) and screenwriter Nicholas Stoller (Neighbors) get remarkably steady comic rewards out of whoopee cushions and toilets.
movie_title: Captain Underpants: The First Epic Movie (Captain Underpants) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Gross-out gags can be hilarious, but not so much here.
movie_title: Diary Of A Wimpy Kid: The Long Haul (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Thankfully, Saunders can still write acidic barbs, and she and director Mandie Fletcher, who has helmed the most recent versions of the series, come up with a seemingly endless series of entertaining cameos featuring real-life fashion titans.

Despite its frosty setting, the first Ice Age warmed viewers' hearts back in 2002. Now the animated critters from the first movie succeed in making the audience's eyelids feel heavy in Ice Age: Collision Course.
Wiig and McCarthy, for the most part, serve as decent straight women to McKinnon and Jones, but it seems as if Feig is underutilizing his formidable leading ladies.
Mike and Dave Need Wedding Dates proves that raunchy, booze-soaked comedies work only when the audience has more fun than the people on screen.
movie_title: Mike and Dave Need Wedding Dates (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The crews of the Pendleton and of the CG-36500, which rescued them, demonstrated formidable courage and ingenuity in coming out of the devastating nor'easter alive. These folks deserve more than a middling January release.

At least Allegiant takes its team of rebels outside of the gloomy, forbidding walls of a rotting futuristic Chicago. Unfortunately, it treats the audience to a dour landscape and a cold, hi-tech palace.
For all the skin and sunshine in A Bigger Splash, Guadagnino and screenwriter David Kajganich manage to make charming places and beautiful people seem pretty unsettling.
While I'm happy that Anna and her family are doing well, it's too bad that the movie that's based on their lives seems less than miraculous.
Keeping all of the strong personalities corralled while keeping sequel-itis to a minimum is a formidable achievement.

While it has its share of gunplay and property damage... The Infiltrator earns its chills not by pummeling the audience with violence but by gently reminding viewers that some businesses only offer permanent severance packages.
How much time do we want to spend with people who would love to have keggers when they're on the verge of buying a second home?
Nicolas-Troyan can handle special effects but his fantasy world looks less enchanting than a sanitary landfill. Everything is gray, flat and blurry.
If you really love your parents, as I do, don't let them spend their hard-earned cash on Marshall's half-hearted effort.
Despite a good deal of chaotic action and visual overkill (nothing is small in this movie), the story feels oddly thin and the running time feels padded.
The Wild Life starts with a shaky idea and goes downhill from there.
Although it's based on Rick Yancey's young adult novels (two so far, and counting), The 5th Wave feels more as if it were cobbled together from a host of other, better science fiction stories.
Ride Along 2 follows in the indifferent footsteps of its predecessor.
If you spent 86 minutes crawling through a snowbank while clad only in a bathing suit, it would probably be a more rewarding experience than sitting through Norm of the North.
For the most part, Lee and company still manage to coax solid laughs and to give the grim facts the gravity they deserve.
A movie was inevitable. Maybe we're lucky Clint Eastwood and Tom Hanks were there to direct and star in the film.
Washington is still the star of the film, but he stands out by underplaying while his peers go over the top. He provides a calm center as Fuqua stages some expert gunplay and equine action.
It's fun to watch Burton max out the capabilities of computer generated-imagery. But it would be even more enjoyable if the characters were equally imaginative.
movie_title: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Just once it would be refreshing if a movie about a genius treated the audience as if they had half of the protagonist's brainpower.

Hart's formidable gifts as a storyteller are supplemented by his compact but agile physique that enables him to contort himself into positions that a kinesthesiologist would be hard pressed to explain.
Streep walks a careful line between Jenkins' silliness and her worthy heart. Florence Foster Jenkins would lose its appeal quickly if she were merely a woman with a fat purse and a lousy voice.

Thanks to Field's ability to give data entry clerk Doris Miller a consistent sense of dignity, it's easy to cheer for a character who'd be an eccentric or even annoying supporting character in other films.
Rowling demonstrates that her eye for character is as sharp as her imagination.
movie_title: Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Paz's return to the ring is inherently inspiring, so writer-director Ben Younger is already off to a good start, but Younger adds some intriguing touches that give the film a feeling of authenticity that makes the Cinderella story seem less sappy.

Maui isn't the only visual delight in Moana, but he's easily the standout. The lush 3-D depictions of the South Pacific actually make wearing the glasses and shelling out a few extra bucks worthwhile.
Screenwriter Katie Dippold comes up with just enough surprising ways for Emily and Linda to get in and out of trouble to make Snatched more than a cascade of bodily fluids.
With all the complicated emotions involved, it's easy to see why Ozon uses color sparingly.

Having seen more than my share of movies where the filmmakers seem to hoping that that audiences won't notice when their craftsmanship is sloppy, it's refreshing to see a movie that invites viewers to soak in the details.

If it were merely a dramedy about an alcoholic trying to get sober and find her purpose in life, Colossal might still work... but the metaphor allows the movie to explore how actions in one part of the world have consequences elsewhere.

Nonetheless, Their Finest is one of the few movies about making movies that is fun to watch in its own right. If you have trouble telling one end of a camera from another, you're still likely to enjoy it.
Essentially a watered-down version of Searching for Bobby Fischer, Gifted is earnest but phony.
[Vigolondo] knows how to say we're all in this small blue ball together without limiting his imagination to the confines of Earth's atmosphere.

To Morgan's credit, he can write a lot of snappy banter among Deckard and Hobbs and Roman and Tej. Listening to these guys taunt each other is a good way to get through the gaps between chases and crashes.
Unlike a lot of filmmakers on this side of the Atlantic, Assayas lets a few mysteries remain once Personal Shopper is over. Mysteries lose much of their power if they are analyzed to death.

Director Zach Braff (Garden State, Wish I Was Here) and screenwriter Theodore Melfi (Hidden Figures, Saint Vincent) have made at least one decent film apiece but don't seem to have any idea why their previous films worked.

The stakes in Land of Mine are certainly high, and the situation is urgent. Nonetheless, Zandvliet has trouble getting the story to move. While it's easy to see why the lads burst into tears often, 100 minutes of it can get redundant quickly.

The Boss Baby is at its most enjoyable when viewers, like Tim himself, have to figure out what is real and what is make believe. If Alec Baldwin delivers a PowerPoint presentation of dull material, it's still dull.
Not so much a movie as it is a collection of future YouTube clips.
By adapting the segments into a script, the story seems choppy and lacks some dynamics. Despite a series of comic catastrophes, Wilson never seems to grow or develop.
The stakes involved don't seem terribly urgent, and none of the characters are engaging enough to make Sam's feuds and friendships with them seem interesting.
The storyline feels as if little has progressed since the initial pitch meeting, and the dialogue sounds as if someone pasted expletives in the place of the punctuation marks.
[Verbinski is] more at home making viewers squirm than in indulging in Johnny Depp's whimsy.
The script, which seems like a William S. Burroughs copy and paste experiment, doesn't give any of the thespians much room to work.
If Kolstad and Stahelski repeat themselves on a couple of occasions, they make up for it by setting the mayhem in stylized environments.
Get the Girl has a few intriguing touches.
Terry Stacey's photography can be as warm and inviting as a lap dog, but it's difficult to invest in any particular dog when we know it's going to come back to life like a video game character.

It's the sort of outlandish setup one might expect from The Sixth Sense mastermind M. Night Shyamalan, and thanks to inspired turns from Taylor-Joy and Scottish actor James McAvoy, Split is often as engrossing as it is implausible.
Like those cars, Live by Night manages to get viewers to their destination, but it's a bumpy and uncomfortable ride.

Cranston starred in sitcoms like Malcolm in the Middle before Breaking Bad gave him the role of a lifetime. He's such a talented performer he doesn't need writers as good as Vince Gilligan. But he needs better than this.
There's a legion of familiar voices featured in Sing, but they aren't used that judiciously. It's hard to appreciate an all-star voice cast when the material doesn't give them much to do.
It's an odd film where the actor playing an Uber driver (Fortune Feimster) gets more laughs than the top billed stars. Perhaps there's a better party in her car.
Just as Miller's plays have been worthwhile exports, Farhadi's movies can help us better understand his culture and our own.
Di Gregorio has a low-key, unaffected charm that makes it remarkably easy to relate to his semi-autobiographical movies.
movie_title: Gianni e le donne (The Salt of Life) (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Daddy's Home 2 makes me feel sorry for disparaging A Bad Moms Christmas. That movie is still lacking, but at least the filmmakers managed to get the most out of the actors who played the bad grandmas.
'Downtown Express' is a charming, if somewhat familiar, movie that becomes extraordinary because it has astonishingly good music.
Neither the former sitcom star nor the washboard-abed Scotsman is served well here.
Perhaps director Thor Freudenthal might have made a somewhat more satisfying film if he'd assumed the viewers were grown up as well.
Sadly, the most memorable aspect of the film is a groan-inducing surprise ending that trivializes a horrific catastrophe and reminds viewers how vapid the rest of the movie is.

Imagine an Iraq War film without the terrifying suspense of The Hurt Locker, the empathy of The Messenger or the lacerating wit of In the Loop, and you get an idea of what it's like to sit through Green Zone.
Chicago-based documentarian Joe Winston makes a valiant effort to make Frank's perspectives work on screen.
If the Man has got you down and your VHS copies of 'Shaft,' 'Superfly,' 'Dolemite' and 'I'm Gonna Git You Sucka' are all worn out, 'Black Dynamite' is here to save the day.
Despite the modest resources, 'Moon' is so visually astonishing that it almost looks like it was shot on location on Earth's oldest satellite.
The images rival anything Burton has created for 'Big Fish' and 'Edward Scissorhands,' but the storytelling isn't quite as engagingly odd.
'Brooklyn's Finest' juggles three separate but interlocking storylines, and it takes considerable effort and intense audience concentration to decide which of the trio is the most tedious.
It's refreshing to see that Polanski can still make thrillers that never take a viewer's intelligence for granted.
Despite some strikingly flourishes, von Trier's latest makes him look less like a mad genius and more like he's simply, mad.
At least the title for 'Cop Out' seems appropriate.
For over two hours, Shutter Island coasts by on creepy atmosphere alone.
Throughout the film Holbrook does nothing to soften his potentially unlikable character and winds up earning respect, and even a little affection in the process.
As I started to type out the plot threads, it struck me that none of the storylines are that interesting to read. They aren't that much fun to watch either.

Despite the a classic pedigree and a cast full of Oscar winners and nominees, the script credited to Andrew Kevin Walker and David Self never develops the characters into the first or second dimension, much less the third.
In 'From Paris with Love,' Wax destroys half of the City of Light's underworld in order to stop either a drug ring or a terrorist cell.
Thanks to some ingenious editing, 'The Most Dangerous Man in American' never feels like a dry history lecture.
movie_title: Most Dangerous Man in America: Daniel Ellsberg and the Pentagon Papers (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Charles Darwin is such a polarizing figure that trying to make a credible portrait of him is almost impossible. I'm willing to give director Jon Amiel ('Entrapment') credit for at least trying.
Now that Lembeck has tarnished another dear childhood memory, perhaps he can call it a day before he desecrates our image of the Easter Bunny.
Emotionally, the new film would have been better titled, 'Routine Tasks.'
Ford makes viewers dive head first into one man's grief and despair but also manages to make a film that is vibrant and engaging because of its sadness.
Because Peter Jackson is willing to wrestle with challenging material, it's easy to forgive him if he doesn't create additional masterpieces every time he steps behind the camera.
There's slothfulness to the script that permeates the entire film. 'Leap Year' has been pasted together with a 'maybe the audience won't notice' attitude.
Cera proves that he can also do more than capitalize on his boyish face.
After watching the film, I had to consult the movie's web site to remember who was who. I'm still attempting to find a reason for why I should care about this sloppily conceived and executed film.
I'm not sure I'd want to download a podcast of Meryl Streep or Alec Baldwin reading the instructions to a 1040 form, but I'd imagine both could make the material become more pleasantly vibrant.
'Waking Sleeping Beauty' is less of a documentary and more of a goldmine for animation geeks.
Clash of the Titans: Liam Neeson sounds/cool saying, "Release the Kraken."/Harryhausen weeps

Ajami may be set in Israel, but at times it plays more like an American gangster drama. The film does address the ethnic and social tensions that run through the country, but it does so in a nuanced and refreshingly clear-eyed way.
Explosions are a lot more fun when they don't look as if they are happening on the same machine that will be hosting Guitar Hero in a few minutes.
The subject matter is likely to enrage and for all the appropriate reasons.
movie_title: Casino Jack And The United States Of Money (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Instead of spending $20 or more on tickets to Marmaduke, read the original strip for free at http://comics.com/marmaduke. In addition to the more agreeable price, it also has more laughs.
Splice is one of those rare creature features where the most menacing beings are the people.
Still, there are enough moments when the characters quit talking and start climbing or fencing so that passively watching the proceedings isn't as dull as waiting for your turn at the controls.
movie_title: Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time (2010)

movie_review_blurb: After all, bad films need love, too.
Novice feature director Gianni Di Gregorio has made a terrific and warm little comedy by only occasionally leaving his apartment in Rome.
Unfortunately, the main couple in the film competes in vain against the scenery.
You know you're in trouble when it takes two and a half hours for the legend to, well, begin.
Watching 'Words of Advice: William S. Burroughs on the Road' gives viewers a chance to see what the writer and multimedia innovator was like in his final years.
movie_title: Words of Advice: William S. Burroughs On the Road (2007)

movie_review_blurb: You'd have to have a heart as hard as Iron Man's armor not to be moved by this thoughtful documentary by Geralyn Pezanoski.
Don Argott's new documentary makes some of the most outlandish conspiracy theories seem strangely believable.
Probably the most refreshing trait in Jon Favreau's Iron Man movies is that the most entertaining moments come when there's no action to speak of.
This German entry benefits from a matter-of-fact approach.
When sharp and funny performers like Steve Carell and Tina Fey are running on all cylinders, their vehicle doesn't have to be that classy.
The Swedish thriller 'The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo' miraculously causes the adjectives 'convoluted' and 'implausible' to become positive
movie_title: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2009)

movie_review_blurb: What keeps The Runaways from becoming yet another story of a group being exploited by a Svengali-like manager is that Sigismondi frames the story by having the girls learn from Fowley before slowly discovering how to develop skills that leave him in the d
According to writer-director Raymond De Felitta's blog entries on Salon.com, he has worked a long time to get his new movie City Island to the screen, maybe a little too long.
This adaptation of Mark Millar's comic books has enough biting wit and bone crunching action to justify the title.
If Vincere gives viewers a new angle on a seemingly familiar subject, it's worth catching primarily for Mezzogiorno's sympathetic turn as Dalser.
Furry Vengeance is heavy on eco-moralizing and poop jokes but a little short on likable two-legged characters.

When producers Michael Bay, Andrew Form and Bradley Fuller go to sleep tonight, it's a safe bet that their dreams will be tormented by Wes Craven and Robert Englund sporting gloves with bladed fingers.
It's frightening to think that the makers of this effort have confused relentless monotony with terror.
Miley Cyrus is/too tall to be Hannah now,/ so she makes Sparks fizzle.
Unlike a lot of ripped from the headlines films, André Téchiné's 'The Girl on the Train' makes no effort to surprise viewers with unflattering or tragic revelations about its protagonists.
movie_title: The Girl on the Train (La Fille du RER) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: For the most part, quirky British filmmaker Guy Ritchie has managed to take the character out of mothballs without desecrating Conan Doyle's original vision.

The fact that the 79-year-old Frederick Wiseman is still making movies after his debut in the mid-1960s demonstrates that there's still a market for his work, and if he continues to make first rate documentaries like' La Danse: The Paris Opera Ballet,' th
movie_title: La Danse -- Le Ballet de l'Opera de Paris (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Perhaps only George Clooney could make getting fired sound like a positive development.
'The Invention of Lying' is based on a simple idea, but Gervais and Robinson come up with seemingly endless ways to maximize it.
With 'Bright Star,' New Zealand's Jane Campion ('The Piano') has managed to write and direct an engrossing film about a man whose achievements can only be found on the page and in the heart.
The new remake of the 1980 hit 'Fame' is not going to live forever and has clearly not learned how to fly.
While 'Cloudy with a Chance of Meatballs' would probably still be entertaining in a conventional 2D format, the story is a natural for 3D.
movie_title: Cloudy With a Chance of Meatballs (2009)

movie_review_blurb: If Soderbergh's offbeat approach seems alienating at first, the film's second half is loaded with hilariously bizarre revelations, which are actually true to the case.

From watching the new documentary 'The September Issue,' it's hard to tell if novelist and former Anna Wintour assistant Lauren Weisberger was unfair to the editor when she created the relentlessly cruel Miranda Priestly.
Because '9' runs only 79 minutes, Acker almost gets by on the intricate and distinctive visuals.
British actor Hugh Dancy manages an astonishing feat by making viewers empathize with a character that has trouble feeling empathy.
Jennifer Steinman's new documentary 'Motherland' follows a group of American women who attempt to get beyond their own suffering.
Whereas several recent films like the pompous 'Lions for Lambs' presented the current war in a didactically solemn tone, Iannucci has more to say by simply playing the crisis for laughs.
There's some jaw dropping eye candy in 'X Games 3D: The Movie,' but there are also wasted opportunities.
Tarantino assembles his complicated plot and multitude of players with only occasional allegiance to history. As a result, all bets are off, making the film and its twists harder to predict.
Unless your idea of cinematic bliss is a chance to catch Bana's buff torso or shoulders, there isn't much to the film.
'Paper Heart' is a strange hybrid of documentary and fiction filmmaking that might have been more enjoyable had it stuck with strictly with the facts.
Co-writer-director Todd Graff doesn't look at teens or their issues in a condescending light.
'Ponyo' is a worthy piece of work from an artist who takes his work and his audience seriously.
This broken affair is more entertaining than most successful ones.
Bruckheimer and his crew should have imagined material that's suited for more than the bottom of a cage.

While the Harry Potter movies have always been a wonderful excuse for jaw dropping special effects, it's gratifying to see the fantasy landscapes populated by wizards and witches with flesh-and-blood personalities.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (2009)

movie_review_blurb: But by pointing out how low some people will sink to hit the heights of fame, Baron Cohen can raise as many valid discussions as he can squirms.
Thanks to a radiant performance from Michelle Pfeiffer, 'Chéri' occasionally overcomes a storyline that never quite develops momentum.
The film's story is so dry and unimaginative that it appears to have been preserved in amber from an earlier era.
movie_title: Ice Age: Dawn of the Dinosaurs (Ice Age 3) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: 'Away We Go' is still funny and occasionally touching, but it might have been even more entertaining if Mendes and the screenwriters hadn't tried to so hard to make us laugh.
'Outrage' makes a convincing argument that legislating while living in the closet is detrimental to everyone.
'Think Like a Man' is a unique achievement in cinema. It is possibly the first two-hour big screen informercial.
It might seem like a fantasy for the baker interviewed in the film to be making $60,000 a year and benefits, but Moore proves the idea is less fictitious than the ones that sank Lehman Brothers.
Oscar-winning Polish writer/director Andrzej Wajda is now 83 years old. But he thankfully hasn't lost his ability to outrage viewers for all the right reasons.
Bell's charm and finesse with a right hook help elevate Angel of Death from being a mundane straight-to-DVD offering.
Hicks' rambling pacing and Cubitt's routine approach to the story prevent 'The Boys Are Back' from reaching its potential.

It's not an insult to say that 'Me and Orson Welles' lacks the audacity that Welles brought to movies, radio and the stage. By merely reminding viewers of Welles and his achievements, it's not hard to imagine his silky baritone bellowing with approval.

When James Cameron boasts about his latest macro-budgeted movie pushes the limits of cinema, he sounds like a politician bragging about a pork barrel project. Unlike elected officials, Cameron actually delivers.
Perhaps "The Private Lives of Pippa Lee" might have been a stronger film had it focused on a single private life instead of a cornucopia of them.
movie_title: The Private Lives of Pippa Lee (2009)

movie_review_blurb: It's a step backward in technology, but it's not a step down in entertainment.
What's so refreshing about 'Anvil: The Story of Anvil' is that it focuses on a Toronto band named Anvil who have been playing for 30 years despite having no commercial success to show for it.
'Crude,' thankfully, brings insight and urgency to an issue that has until recently been ignored
Screenwriter Geoffrey Fletcher and director Lee Daniels manage to pile on the misfortunes without making 'Precious' maudlin or dour.
movie_title: Precious: Based on the Novel Push by Sapphire (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Writer-director Wes Anderson's movies are often loaded with cartoonish characters and situations. So, it would only make sense that his most enjoyable movie to date is an actual cartoon.
Because of the nature of its subject matter, 'The Messenger' is emotionally charged, but director Oren Moverman and his able cast prevent it from feeling phony or manipulative.
Despite some wonderful performances and memorable situations, writer-director Cédric Klapisch ('L'Auberge Espagnole') fails to recapture the warmth of his previous ensemble dramas.
Based on the quality of its script, 'Old Dogs' should have been put to sleep before the cameras started rolling.
The plot's pretty basic, but it's surprisingly hard to follow.
It shouldn't be surprising that Pixar can make a sequel that retains all the charm of the film that preceded it. After all, they've done it before.
Movies like '2012' wreck the world in front of our eyes through long pageants of explosions. 'The Road,' however, deals with cataclysmic ruin in a far different and much more compelling manner.
Because of this new, but thoroughly chaste love triangle, "The Twilight Saga: New Moon" is inept and annoying in a different way than its predecessor.
Kent Mackenzie's 1961 movie 'The Exiles' was so revolutionary that even now it seems gutsy.
'The Damned United' is a soccer movie that's really about a man's struggle with his most dangerous opponent--his own ego.

It's pointless to fault '2012' for being silly or perpetuating scientific and historic baloney. Instead, the new movie's unforgivable transgression is that it fails to make any of the apocalyptic destruction fun.
