Just when you expect the film to do something normal, it takes off like Murray -- riffing on reality as only he, and filmmaker Anderson, can.
Much of what happens feels rough, as if Anderson never completed his shooting script... But individual moments... just might keep you entertained throughout the film's near-two-hour running time
movie_title: The Life Aquatic with Steve Zissou (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Good acting, shotmaking and a charismatic lead role alone won't grant you a pass to Kubrick country. Nor even to Costner country.
It's as compelling as a car commercial, as deep as a diaper pail.
Its Claymation images, bizarrely imagined as they are, can't begin to mask the range of emotions Barras' characters want to convey.
movie_title: My Life as a Zucchini (Ma vie de courgette) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Former child star Saoirse Ronan - the girl in Joe Wright's masterful 2007 film Atonement - shines.
The Boss Baby is a funny, clever take on sibling rivalry that should appeal both to children -- especially those who, we can be thankful, are removed from politics -- and their parents.
[I Called Him Morgan is] a film that is more than just another story about a flawed artist who dies young. You have something that is far closer to a work of art.
Comic and enlightening.
It is [Robert] Pattinson who shines. Once a vampire hunk, he has grown into the kind of actor the camera loves - even if preteen girls no longer will.

Wind River may be [the native's] home, but this is Lambert's story. He, in the end, is the great white savior - which is a plot device Hollywood has been using since well before the days of John Ford and Howard Hawks.
[Kathryn] Bigelow's use of her cast is impressive, even if limited screen time means that no one actor has what amounts to a starring role.
[Idris] Elba, is a revelation. Few actors have the kind of personal power that can make evil seem, at first, so attractive but then, finally, merely pathetic.
Director [Angelina] Jolie documents all this with inordinate skill.

Bridge of Spies is, as an example of mainstream entertainment, a beautiful achievement. For those of us who want a bit more authenticity, though, it's clear that even while portraying dark events, Steven Spielberg only rarely strays away from the light.
Give us traditional wink-wink Bond or give us the new seriousness. This hybrid version feels neither shaken nor stirred.
Seldom has a documentary immersed itself so far inside the culture it is portraying and with such devastating effect.
Never has a pre-teen pulled off a more adult performance.
Filmmaker Joshua Oppenheimer knows well the power of contrast.
[Todd] Haynes remains the consummate filmmaking artist.

An examination of whether vigilante justice - no matter how well-intentioned at the start - is doomed, ultimately, to become just another example of would-be good guys falling prey to the lure of egotism and/or big money.

I was NOT prepared for was just how beautiful the visuals Hou [Hsia-Hsein] gives us would be - beautiful to the point that I ultimately didn't care at all whether I understood what The Assassin was trying to say.

It's impossible to deny the visceral, visual power of what [Alejandro González Iñárritu] has put on the screen - a power that feels more like you've been pulled directly into the screen instead of merely sitting in front of it.
White understands that such feelings are, for most of us, fleeting - the kinds of emotions that we entertain, then either ignore, forget or simply laugh off. It takes Brad a while longer.
A heart and soul - though his character here would deny that last part - provided by the inimitable Stanton, one of cinema's most unforgettable presences.
Zandvliet's film succeeds mostly because of Møller.
Like any good spy film, "Red Sparrow" has a number of twists that you may not see coming. In this way, it resembles another popular series, "Mission: Impossible."
But most of all, "Game Night" belongs to Bateman and McAdams. No one can chew on a squeaky toy more humorously than he can, and no one is better at combining comic timing and sex appeal than she.
As Grahame, Annette Bening captures both the actress's vulnerability and her flintiness, holding her own against a case of talented British actors
movie_title: Film Stars Don't Die in Liverpool (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Certainly, it's no "Mystic River" or "Letters from Iwo Jima." But at least in technical terms it does display the professional quality that marks Eastwood's typical filmmaking style.

But the star, as always in an Anderson movie, is the writer-director himself. As "Phantom Thread" progresses, Anderson keeps us off-balance, never quite explaining what each character is up to as he or she moves from one scene to the next.

Throughout all this, [Jackie] Chan plays a character we've seldom seen. A quiet man, his Quan is at first composed and careful, then grief-stricken and finally grimly determined. Even then, he is no Rambo.

The cast is brilliant. Margot Robbie, who learned to skate for the film, nails Harding, while Golden-Globe winner Allison Janney is an acerbic marvel as her mother. Sebastian Stan gives a mostly understated performance as Gillooly.

Cinematographer Vittorio Storaro expertly uses the shifting lights of Coney Island's attractions to mirror each scene's shifting moods. Allen's camera movement around Humpty and Ginny's cramped apartment is especially skillful.
And the animation itself is superb, its renderings of the land of the dead even more vibrant than that of the living. That's ironic. Pero también es interesante, no?

Östlund fills his film with uncomfortable moments - off-screen noises, crying babies, and one confounding sequence involving an artiste impersonating an ape - but it's all in service of an idea: Hypocrisy, thy name is the 21st century.
What Gerwig has done is skillfully create a world where her characters can fully develop.
That discovery comes slowly, but inexorably, and in Baker's talented hands, ends up feeling - at the film's end - both like an act of love ... and a punch to the heart.
It is those works, flowing with life, that set "Loving Vincent" apart from your standard life study. And they are what underscores that film title's very meaning.
It is [Gary] Oldman, though, who rules. As he did while portraying characters as diverse as punk-rocker Sid Vicious and the fictional spy George Smiley, Oldman again disappears into the role.
Much as Amy, Asif Kapadia's Oscar-nominated documentary does for Amy Winehouse, it ensures that [Nina] Simone's legacy, both as a woman and an artist, won't be soon forgotten.
Creed is Rocky's movie. Same as it ever was.
Hmmm, dark jokes disguising a possibly serious subtext. Now, isn't that ironic?
What's ironic is that this darkest of tales is told in a uniquely beautiful manner.
Having Captain Jack Sparrow step onto the scene would have been far more believable.
movie_title: Valerian and the City of a Thousand Planets (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Mundane moments are far more prevalent in real life than the melodramatic ones. Which is one of the things I most appreciate about Maudie, Irish filmmaker Aisling Walsh's look at the life of folk artist Maud Lewis.
If the mark of a filmmaker depends both on style and substance, Sofia Coppola is stronger on the former than she is on the latter.
Have the Coens crafted a biting satire? Is this a love letter to classic Hollywood? Is it both? Neither? I wish I could say.

Much is what Shults does is admirable, from his refusal to offer only the barest of exposition to his camera-work, in which he haunts the house's hallways, making it feel near-claustrophobic. What's lacking is a larger sense of purpose.
Not that I didn't like the film. I just didn't like everything about it.
A Quiet Passion does succeed in portraying the ultimate irony: that a woman whose life was filled with so much anguish could leave behind such a rich legacy of literary beauty.

The acting is good across the board, with Ernst Stötzner a gruff presence as Frantz's father, Marie Gruber a far more gracious but no less heartbroken mother. Niney has sharp facial feature that give him a naturally screen-classic air.
Your Name. is a treasure that -- even if the first half hour felt confusing to my own Western-educated mind -- is well worth the investment of a near-two-hour view.

While Weir's story, which screenwriter Drew Goddard adapted for Scott, may not be particularly profound -- we're not talking Blade Runner here, after all -- it is memorable. Which just shows you what a little attitude can accomplish.

Zemeckis -- relying both on Gordon-Levitt's energy and regular glimpses of Manhattan streets from more than 400 meters in the air -- manages to maintain a sense of tension. Even for those of us who know full well what happens.
Weitz may not end up making us like this hard-nosed Grandma. Some of us, though, manage to end up understanding her. And that may be all that's needed.
It is McKellen whose talents are on best display. And he doesn't disappoint. As Holmes, Gandalf or Hamlet, McKellen never does.
What does set Rogue Nation apart, beyond the dependable presence of Cruise, is the humorous subtext - best displayed by Simon Pegg, as funny here as he is in J.J. Abrams' reboot of Star Trek.
In the end, Fuqua has made less a magnificent seven than, at best, a slightly better than average one.
Sully is an inspiring story that didn't need any added drama
Most of all, it benefits from the presence of Sam Elliott, still abiding after all these years.
It's as if [Herzog] wants to understand how life works while harboring a deep-seated realization that it's all just a horrible mistake.
movie_title: Lo and Behold, Reveries of the Connected World (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Under any other circumstances, Saul's devotion to his mission might seem baffling. But, then, as any camp survivor can tell you, hell requires it own sense of logic.
The Light Between Oceans never quite gels into the bona-fide drama it pretends to be.
[Melissa] Rauch shows that when The Big Bang Theory finally runs its course, she might be the one cast member with a movie future.

[Tom] Hardy doesn't just act. He doesn't just become a screen character. He embodies the real-life personalities he is attempting to portray and ends up achieving something that warrants such adjectives as dynamic and fearless and even unforgettable.
The bludgeoning, butchering and bloodletting gets more than a bit old.
Keanu is better than what a lot of veteran Saturday Night Live comics have brought to the big screen, no small feat.
Colliding Dreams - for all the fatalistic implications of that title - does offer some sense of hope, a feeling that, ultimately, time may yet soften the hard edge of history.
The Lobster seem funny. But that feeling fades, leaving us with a sense of fatalism but without a larger sense of actual meaning.
After the first half hour, The Conjuring 2 devolves into a paint-by-number CGI exercise.
Kids may crack up, but adults are more likely to spend their time pondering why the popcorn is so pricey.
The result of all this could work as metaphor, if it weren't so obvious and so glaringly pretentious.
Hunt for the Wilderpeople tackles some fairly serious issues, but it handles those issues with just the right sense of the sweet.
[Music] both nourish and help meld our disparate souls. And sometimes that's enough.
movie_title: The Music of Strangers: Yo-Yo Ma and the Silk Road Ensemble (2016)

movie_review_blurb: In the end, "Sing Street" may cause you to grimace, it may also inspire you to find your own song.
Even if you're not a fan of Doctor Who, if you're left unmoved by this wonderful programme, then there's something wrong with your hearts.
movie_title: An Adventure in Space and Time (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Lymelife, directed by first-timer Derick Martini and produced by Martin Scorsese, balances grimness and levity with relative success.
Not a bad premise -- it's kind of like The Princess Diaries meets Kill Bill meets Terminator 2 -- but the movie doesn't make one right turn.
Under the direction of, say, Alexander Payne or David O. Russell, Malkovich might have flourished in a deeper, darker, more madcap version of the film.

Sunshine Cleaning should have been a madcap comedy of the macabre, or a tangled yarn about the metaphorical biohazards of living life at the margins, but it shoots for the middle and ends up being just that: middling.
An earnest, fictional coming-of-age story is squeezed from a bitter, true-life local tragedy. And it works.

In a comedy era ennobled by the crackling wit of Vince Vaughn, Steve Carell and Tina Fey, Yes Man comes across as innocent, quaint, pitiable, as one-note as borscht belt humor and not committed enough to support great slapstick.
The movie knows it's a slasher flick made solely for commerce, it knows we know what it is, and yet it insists on feigning the song and dance.
It's the perfect brain vacation for those overtaxed by Oscar-nominated movies.
Several maraschino cherries short of a fruitcake.
Elsa & Fred feels not substantial enough to bear the weight of its themes. It dissolves like cotton candy, making proper digestion impossible.
Reno 911!: Miami will suffice for fans hungry for new material and tired of waiting for the show's fourth season to end or the fifth to start.
As far as the crazy-stalker-chick genre goes, Obsessed isn't horrible. It's just intensely simple-minded.
A drama about sibling rivalry and reconciliation that just happens to be filmed under extremely dangerous circumstances.
The film transforms Rose's play into a ballet of sorts. The story is as much about movement as it is about words.
The Mysteries of Pittsburgh seems to be missing an essential element of drama, of risk, underneath its glossy, golden sheen.
A ponderous tragedy about put-upon manhood? A verite snoop into cultures that are sexually mingled but publicly uneasy? A pill to be swallowed in the name of serious filmgoing? Maybe all of these.
movie_title: La Graine et le Mulet (The Secret of the Grain) (Couscous) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Sin Nombre is pure filmmaking: a great story told in beautiful images.
Why couldn't Couples Retreat have been lighthearted and zany throughout, instead of trying to push across a message about picket-fence monogamy?
Extract may be the most disappointing American comedy of the decade, partly because it's jokeless and joyless but mostly because it squanders an all-star cast of superb comic talent.
Storywise, Moon fails to live up to the promise of its premise. There's plenty of atmosphere, but little gravity.
Adorable, moving, bewildering, sad and, ultimately, peaceful.
Public Enemies, despite packing thunderous rounds of ammunition, is a touch too remote.
The peculiar, comic-book-like computer graphics -- artful at first -- finally overtake Blood and make it look like a video game instead of a graceful, graphic martial arts movie.
At times tedious but ultimately beguiling, Song of Sparrows morphs from a sly dramedy about running a household into a fable about two ways of life (urban and rural) that can't coexist.
What might've been a scrumptious, chocolatey dessert of a movie -- a Noel Coward delite -- is instead a scoop of lemon ice, not filling, faintly sweet and mostly water.
Adoration is a delicate rumination on how innocence and truth evolve in the aftermath of catastrophe, as people stake emotional ownership in tragedy.
This is not a sports movie. But for lovers of Luna and Bernal, especially Luna and Bernal together, Rudo y Cursi will be a quick, harmless, caffeinated booster shot until their next collaboration.
Jarmusch has taken the idea of a caper, drained it of plot, action and suspense, and set it against an absurdist background, where every symbol, person and incident should convey meaning but doesn't.
A crisp, efficient, sometimes petty but often infuriating documentary about alleged gay politicians who actively campaign and vote against gay rights.
Depending on your patience for oddball mood pieces, you will either sleep through O' Horten or be oddly captivated. Either way, it'll be like dreaming.
Lowry has a well-developed eye for inventive storytelling thanks to his background in micro-budget shorts. His vision is on full display here, and the result is one of 2017's most powerful films.
And Stiller, who also co-wrote and directs, accessorizes his movie with the same fun and goofy energy as the first, even if the story is thinner than Kate Moss.
Kim's soul-searching is at the heart of it all, and when the movie is focused on her relatable dilemmas it's better than when it's not.
If there's not enough real-life terrorism out there for you, then you can count on "London Has Fallen" to fill the gap with enough violence to blow up world 10 times over.

A crisis of belief ensues, as Clavius, accompanied by his aide (Tom Felton, Draco in the "Harry Potter" movies) sets out to solve the mystery surrounding why Jesus' body disappeared from its sealed tomb. It's "Law and Order: Judean Desert 33 A.D."
The charming script, credited to four writers, turns on a dime when tragedy befalls one of the characters.

"Where to Invade Next" is one of the Oscar-winner's ("Bowling for Columbine") lighter efforts, but it's still entertaining and informative. A brilliant sociologist, Moore has a knack for cutting to the heart of what's the matter with us.

Director Ross Katz, who did last year's well-received "Adult Beginners," works from a script by Bryan Sipe ("Demolition") that summons all the de rigueur contrivances and corny dialogue that hasten tooth decay.
To millions of moviegoers, the force is with us once again, and that is good.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)

movie_review_blurb: You'll be hooked from the get-go. But like that elusive high, you're left wanting more.

You can only take so much of a randy Robert De Niro joking about "taking a number 3" or other stuff that rhymes with truck that I can't repeat. Let's just say all Grandpa wants to do is truck, truck, truck.

Director Bill Condon ("Gods and Monsters," "Dreamgirls") and screenwriter Melissa Rosenberg (she wrote the last one, too) finally get the joke and have crafted a movie that possesses an iota of entertainment value.
movie_title: The Twilight Saga: Breaking Dawn Part 2 (2012)

movie_review_blurb: David O. Russell has a rare misfire with "Joy." Jennifer Lawrence, his muse, in the title role, can't save the movie, either. Nor can Russell regulars Robert De Niro and Bradley Cooper.

Landesman comes out swinging, telling the tragic story of Pittsburgh's beloved center, Iron Mike Webster (an always terrific David Morse) ... Then he pulls back the knife when he should be going for the jugular.
I expected jump-in-my-seat scares. All I got was the fidgets and more laughs, most unintentional, than the last comedy I saw.
Vikander is devastatingly terrific. Her award-worthy performance runs the gamut from heartbreak to desperation to despair to acceptance.
"Pride and Prejudice and Zombies" - the adaptation of the Seth Grahame-Smith book - is a real hoot in some places and a deadly (undeadly?) bore in others. Still, it's hard to completely dismiss it.

Sacrifice is the theme of "Allegiant," the third and unfortunately not final installment in the dystopian "Divergent Series," and that's exactly what I did in subjecting myself to its unique form of YA torture. I took the bullet so you won't have to.
Carney casts a nostalgic glow that never turns into overt sentimentality and hits all the right notes. Growing up is hard, but it goes down easier when the music is this good.
In her sequel, "My Big Fat Greek Wedding 2," Vardalos has lost the Midas touch, delivering nothing fresh or funny in revisiting the loud yet loving Portokalos clan.

The new "Ghostbusters" has its own charms, and the audience I saw it with belly-laughed its approval. "SNL's" McKinnon - easily the funniest woman on TV right now - flat out steals the movie from her co-stars. She's a total gas.

First-time feature (it shows) director Jake Szymanski and "Neighbors" writers Andrew Jay Cohen and Brendan O'Brien squander a good premise by turning their lead characters into a pair of one-dimensional clowns.
movie_title: Mike and Dave Need Wedding Dates (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Skarsgard looks fine on the vine in this reboot helmed by "Harry Potter" director David Yates.
"Central Intelligence" is fun while it lasts, with some big laughs and warm goofiness... Plus, Dwayne Johnson's behemoth biceps alone are worth the price of admission.

Sequels often struggle to measure up. That's the case here. It feels like Wan, a reliable genre director ("Saw," "Insidious"), put forth his greatest hits from those previous efforts and the redundancy haunts "The Conjuring 2."
You go along for the ride because of the presence of Jesse Eisenberg, Woody Harrelson, Morgan Freeman and Mark Ruffalo, hoping they'll pull a rabbit out of the hat.
In "Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Out of the Shadows," you can take the fab four out of the sewers and into the light of New York City, but too much dumbness still lurks in the dark.
movie_title: Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Out of the Shadows (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Seems the committee of five who wrote the script couldn't make lightning strike twice even though they cleverly flip the gender so girls can fight for their right to party.

From British writer-director Terence Davies' ("The Deep Blue Sea"), the movie can at times be cringe-inducing and brutal, yet tender and hopeful in depicting Chris' struggle to find her way in a time when a woman's worth was little.
George Clooney! Julia Roberts! The pedigree behind the set-in-real-time thriller "Money Monster" is reason enough to see the movie.

Brown takes a conventional hit-the-high-note approach in telling the story of an unlikely pairing between Ramanujan (Dev Patel, "Slumdog Millionaire") and an eccentric professor (Jeremy Irons, "Batman v. Superman").

Sorrentino paints a friendship between a pair of octogenarians that feels lived-in. And it rings even more authentic in the largely capable hands of Keitel and Caine, two acting vets with street cred to burn.
It is both a sequel and a prequel to 2012's "Snow White and the Huntsman," but alas, Snow White wasn't even invited to her own party.
The first half of the movie is especially fun when each character who enters sparks a deluge of one-liners, battle-of-the-sexes banter or pop-culture barbs about Kanye, the Kardashians and R. Kelly.

It resonates more than it doesn't, but the part of "Demolition" that really slays you is watching Cooper, who lost his only child when the boy was 17, portray a grieving dad. Those tears are the real deal.
There's a tear in my beer, for sure, after seeing the Hank Williams biopic "I Saw the Light," a too simple a portrait of a complex man.
Richard Linklater's collegiate comedy "Everybody Wants Some!!" is a two-exclamation-point romp.
Director Gavin Hood takes a daring look at the toll war takes on everyone... you'll be sitting at the edge of your seat debating what you'd do.
If you're up for an homage to Rocky, then ding-ding, "Creed" answers the bell.

Uncorking a non-stop deluge of motion and his trademark rigueur whiplash dialogue, Sorkin sticks to his lonesome belief that words speak louder than pictures. And you know what? In his case they do - beautifully.

The script contrivances alone are enough to sink Billy Ray's tepid remake of the Argentine Oscar-winning crime drama "Secret in Their Eyes." Or, it would be if not for the top-notch performances from the director's deep and talented cast.
What you won't see coming is the nuanced and confident performance by Kristen Stewart, better known to the world as Bella the pouty vampire lover from the "Twilight" series.
Staying 29 forever is every woman's fantasy. But, as "Gossip Girl" alum Blake Lively finds out in the predictable but endearing love story "The Age of Adaline," that blessing becomes a burden.
Director Joss Whedon's strengths - and better writing - really come through in the quieter moments. Relish those while you can.
"Mad Max: Fury Road" is everything you want your summer blockbuster to be: loaded with insane action, hot actors and death-defying stunts.

Don't be fooled by the gorgeous Hawaiian setting, glossy sheen or star-studded cast ... Looks are deceiving. "Aloha" is a wreck and squanders every ounce of talent those A-listers possess. You'll be embarrassed for them.
While "Entourage" makes no bones about its intent to please its built-in audience, it has just enough mindless pleasures to cross over as well.

All the ingredients for something special coalesce, including an outstanding performance from a fresh-faced Shameik Moore as Malcolm, a fragile everyteen sporting a flat-top straight out of Kid 'n' Play.
The whole package from writer/director Boaz Yakin ("Remember the Titans," "Fresh") rolls over and plays dead.

You'll feel the cold on the Hoth-like ice planet. It's pure movie magic -- impressive and astonishing and deserving of all the out-of-this-world hyperbole. Too bad the rest of it is mostly empty space.
It's a slow and steady mystery with a couple scenes sure to make your jaw drop.

The script suffers from a lack of pathos and is littered with cookie-cutter characters played by terrific actors who collectively have nothing to do but spew expository dialogue, breathe heavy and look befuddled.
Pratt's charm and presence go a long way to carry the film through a confusing first act bogged down in character introductions, back story and set-up.
You never fail to keep your eyes glued to Gyllenhaal.
The run time is 140 minutes, but Flynn and Fincher make it so engrossing, it zips along at breakneck pace.
The more panicked and manic Riggan becomes, the higher Birdman soars.

It's what "Ab Fab" fans have been waiting for ... The rest of us who do not know the 1990s sitcom, which aired on cable in the United States, can only do what Edina and Patsy would tell us to: Piss off, sweetie darlings.
Chef finds Favreau writing, directing, and starring on a much smaller scale, yet still serving up a fully nourishing meal.
The pleasure is in watching Hardy, who's so good that nothing else measures up.
The movie is a weird and darkly comedic exploration of an all-night parental playdate in which marital boredom, sexual dissatisfaction and fidelity are on the agenda.

There's a wealth of material to draw on, almost as if a documentary-to-be-named later was already on someone's mind. In any case, Nachman puts it all to good use, relaying the conception, planning, preparation and execution of the day.

There's nothing warm-and-cozy about the yule dog "Love the Coopers." It should be called "Christmas with the Prigs," given its premise of a pack of privileged brats sitting down to share dinner and whine.
The script from first-time feature writer Morwenna Banks lacks grit and complexity, attributes Hardwicke also disappointingly eschews in playing it safe with trite scenes.

McCarthy ("Win Win," "The Visitor") and his co-writer, Josh Singer ("The Fifth Estate"), smartly focus on the boots-on-the-ground reporting of the Globe's Spotlight team, as it follows lead upon lead to sniff out the biggest scandal in the city's history.
If you can stomach it, seek it out, because Fukunaga delivers a tragic reality that deserves to be seen.
While it's not as frightening as other del Toro offerings, there's no escaping the constant anticipation of having the pants scared off you. It lurks around every atmospheric corner.

Rather than just presenting the audience with a special-effects show, the filmmakers have made a dedicated effort to explore the dilemmas that might result from an astronaut actually being stranded on Mars.
Seriously, 9-year-old boys are hell on wheels. And writer-directors Severin Fiala and Veronika Franz raise the bar on that concept in spinning a twisted tale about Lukas and Elias.
As Cam Stuart, Mark Ruffalo exploits his versatility to convincingly navigate the wild mood swings of manic depression.
It's real, honest, funny and downright predictable, but the Patel family is so engaging and delightful that you wish they'd adopt you.
Mainly, Shyamalan's spookfest suffers from an acute case of monotony.
As the title promises, the movie visits some pretty dark places. It just doesn't know what to with them.
So affecting is the performance by Omar Sy ("Jurassic World," "The Intouchables") as Samba ("like the dance"), an undocumented Senegalese chef, you almost forgive the shortcomings.
The script's biggest mistake? There's nothing at stake, nothing to care about.

There's no dialogue, yet the story comes through loud and clear. It's exactly what ewe expect from Aardman Animation, the claymation geniuses who previously gave us the Wallace and Gromit series and "Chicken Run."
The documentary won't make you a fan of Lego, but you will come away knowing that interest in the toy never stops building.
'Ant-Man" isn't your typical Marvel bombast. Instead of a sensory assault, it's more content with taking a quiet-and-quaint approach to introducing one of the stable's lesser-known superheroes.
The premise is overcooked, but the fine performances from Jason Sudeikis and Alison Brie prop up the pat script.
The titular smartphone game at the heart of the cyber-thriller "Nerve" makes Pokemon Go look like amateur hour.
Even the addition of an Oscar-winning director in Bill Condon ("Kinsey," "Gods and Monsters") fails to save what is essentially a padded-out tale of all-consuming love and loyalty.
As the film's standout, Robbie plays Harley with gusto. Give her a spin off, please.
Ruskin eschews character development, context and depth in favor of brevity.
If you like vicious no-holds-barred hockey fights, then this one is for you.
Never mess with a mother on a mission to save her child.
Director Kathryn Bigelow's film about the 1967 riots in Detroit is a brilliantly mounted recount of an American tragedy. As you'd expect, it goes down like a pound of nails.
Hot on the high-heels of "Rough Night" is "Girls Trip," another female-driven raunch fest. Where they defer in their twin celebrations of sisterhood is that this one is all-caps FUNNY.
It's as if the filmmakers were brainstorming ideas for the Dumb Ways to Die app and came up with a dumb movie instead.
It helps that the story is a true original - one that you have to really see to believe.
"IT'S" bark is worse than its bite.
The third entry arrives in no better shape than either the second movie or its spinoff, "Minions."
"Transformers: The Last Knight" is another huge pyrotechnic porno that leaves a metallic taste in your mouth.
"Cars 3" never fires on all cylinders, but it has considerably more horsepower than the franchise's last chapter
Nothing murders the buzz at a bachelorette party faster than having a stripper turn up dead.
Starlet vs. Shark. It's a sure sign of summer.
This reboot, which Universal Studios is using to launch its cinematic monster franchise, is as stupid as it gets.
Fuel up the Invisible Jet. You're in for a ride.
The bikinis and biceps raunch-com "Baywatch" is - as you'd expect - preposterous. But much to our amusement, the major players are in on the joke, except the joke never evolves.
Wright builds his script on the back of a killer soundtrack.
The plot is inconsequential because in the end it all results in a hodge-podge of provocative images (some sickening) that add up to little more than a big WTF yawn.
"American Assassin" is nothing you haven't seen before.
What pulls you along is Gyllenhaal's performance. You will follow him anywhere.
The movie is simple, small and exudes a certain throwback charm.
Thoroughbreds is dark, violent, twisty, sometimes funny and filled with scathing subtext on wealth, class and privilege.

It's terrific eye candy, filled with dazzling shots of faraway lands saturated in hues of red, orange, green and hot pink, with levitating flowers, and scenes of witches shapeshifting into flying creatures. What's missing is any emotional engagement.
Yes, this "Black Panther" is red-hot. Wakanda forever!
It might have 12 in its title, but make no mistake, the low-rent military drama "12 Strong" is a one-man show for Chris Hemsworth.

In "The Commuter," another late-career actioner, Liam Neeson takes his save-the-day shenanigans aboard the 6:25 train to Cold Spring, a bumpy ride on which he must root out bad guys or it's the end of the line for his family.

Pretty much ill-conceived from the ground up but saved by a couple of strong performances and a wealth of well-researched period detail. Not the most elegant defense, but like the movie, it'll do.
Casting the likes of Downey and Rourke and then imprisoning them in jointed refrigerators is resource-squandering of the highest order.
Its visual splendor more than makes up for its intellectual poverty.
I wouldn't go so far as to recommend this movie, but if you were tied down and forced to watch it, you wouldn't necessarily have to chew off your own leg to get away.
It's a cracking good murder mystery that, by the time the final twist kicks in, transforms into an moving meditation on memory and justice.
movie_title: The Secret in Their Eyes (El Secreto de Sus Ojos) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: What do these characters consider worthy of killing and dying for? That a protagonist lacks superpowers is no reason for him to lack motivation, conviction, or purpose.

It gets one crucial element of comic filmmaking right in a way that few recent comedies have. It's cast, down to the smallest role, with genuinely funny performers, people who understand how to time a joke, deliver a setup, underplay a deadpan glance.

Avatar has taken a lot of heat for being weak on story and overly reliant on visual effects, but compared with this witless, chaotic mess of a movie, James Cameron's epic looks worthy of the ancient Greek authors...

The only Verhoeven element that's missing is deliberate camp, a healthy ladling of which might have made Chloe worth watching for some reason other than the prospect of glimpsing Seyfried's and Moore's admirably formed torsos.
I am genuinely saddened not to have enjoyed Hot Tub Time Machine.
Greenberg's inconclusive last scene hints at the possibility that even the bitterest basket case stands a chance of finding someone who loves him. That's sort of my hope for this movie, too.

There's hope yet for world cinema if an Iranian-American director can take the premise of an Iranian film, set it in North Carolina, cast the lead roles with an African fashion model and Elvis Presley's former bodyguard, and produce something utterly new.
Though it never poses a question more abstract than "Where's that scratching sound coming from?" Paranormal Activity is all about spiritual and ethical debts coming due.
Directed by Mira Nair and executive-produced by its star Hilary Swank, the movie seems oddly preoccupied with the audience's approval for its subject.
Despite the preponderance of (PG-rated) snogging, there are pleasures to be found along this movie's meandering path.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (2009)

movie_review_blurb: It's like spending an afternoon -- a long one -- at a beautifully lit wax-museum display inspired by earlier gangster movies.
By keeping its scale miniature instead of epic (there are no combat scenes in the traditional sense), The Hurt Locker keeps its audience in a constant state of tension without risking battle fatigue.

The simplest thing Bay could have done to clarify the stakes of the robot wars would be to visually distinguish the robots from one another in some way. Armbands? Shirts and skins? "Hello, My Name Is" stickers?

The idea of wedding Woody Allen's comic persona (the introverted nebbish) to Larry David's (the entitled jerk) sounds promising on paper, but as Boris portentously observes just before his unsuccessful suicide attempt, life doesn't take place on paper.

Year One is a slapdash concoction with an overreliance on scatological gags and a long lag time between laughs. I freely admit that. Yet I have a certain affection for this movie, if only because of its conceptual simplicity.
Away We Go is like a disappointing term paper by a promising student.
Land of the Lost is an enjoyable regression to Saturday mornings gone by, as junky and sweet as a strawberry Pop-Tart.
This kind of 'one crazy night' tale relies on drum-tight structure to work. Without it, The Hangover sputters to a sentimental halt.
What's marvelous about Up is how confidently it assumes the audience will smartly follow wherever it wants to take us.
Though the result is thematically slight, it's structurally sophisticated enough to reward a second viewing (or at least, unlike Grey's previous work, to be watched all the way through).
A good summer movie isn't just an uninterrupted crescendo of cacophony. You need stuff in between the fireballs and the cyborgs.
Despite the essential implausibility of the story, Management remains for the most part as endearing as its leads.
One question rings hollowly in the brain for the length this painfully twee romp: What hath Wes Anderson wrought?
If nothing else, Angels & Demons proves that, as McGuffins go, a cylinder of antimatter is more fun than the Holy Grail.
I won't tell you who wins the Rudo/Cursi showdown, but when it comes to the Cuarón brothers, my money's on Alfonso.
Abrams' cannily constructed prequel respects (for the most part) the rules of that world and, more importantly, retains the original Star Trek's spirit of optimism, curiosity, and humor.
Even by the standard of a fourth-in-a-series summer blockbuster, Wolverine is remarkably lame.

It's a movie that's thought-provoking without being intelligent and candid without being truthful. The same aesthetic choices that [director] Toback seems convinced will set his documentary apart are also what diminishes its credibility.
Instead of luring us down an ever-darker and twistier path, it strands us in a tedious and ill-designed maze.

Adventureland, Greg Mottola's tale of coming of age in Pittsburgh in 1987, has the note-perfect melancholy of a classic young adult novel.
If only some sharp-eyed script editor had run 500 Days through the de-sappifying machine, it could have been the first great romantic comedy of 2009.
This Is It is one of the best documents of live performance that I've ever seen, a rehearsal diary that's more intimate and immediate than a traditional concert film.
Humpday may not be the single best movie I've seen so far this year -- though it's certainly a contender for the title -- but it's without doubt the most surprising.
Judd Apatow may be the first filmmaker to jeopardize his career through excessive niceness.
After the infantile bludgeoning that is Antichrist), I feel no need to keep accompanying von Trier's career at all.
If Luis Buñuel had joined forces with the Dogme 95 movement and moved to modern-day Santiago, Chile, he might have made a movie like The Maid.

The result is a pop documentary in the Morgan Spurlock mode, cheeky and smart without being too serious.
As with first love, so with the movies: The right girl makes it all worthwhile.

Despite the ambitious scope of its premise, this confounding, disappointing and, in the end, depressing movie is content to devote 80 percent of its screen time to wondering who gets to kiss the girl.
An exquisitely realized work; the filmmakers' technical mastery of their craft, always impressive, has become absolute.
The rare film about the life of an artist that is itself a work of art.
It's too bad Baumbach's movie is already shot, edited, and up there on the screen, because after a few rounds with a red pencil, it could really have been something worth watching.
Mark's collection of bizarre behaviors doesn't add up to a character.
Kusama and Cody's collaboration is a wicked black comedy with unexpected emotional resonance, one of the most purely pleasurable movies of the year so far.

Like Judge's first two live-action films, Extract seems destined to do minor business at the box office but achieve a kind of immortality as a cult DVD.
With its unremittingly bleak humor and eagerness to plumb the depths of fanboy abjection, Big Fan seems destined for a future in the cult canon.

Even as a mind-clearing break from Lee's darker, more ambitious work, Taking Woodstock is an underachieving movie, so slight and gentle-spirited that it seems to be looking at the summer of 1969 through a scrim of rosy gauze.

This starkly unromantic epic ultimately benefits from its 150-minute running time, immersing the audience in the RAF's journey from shared passion to collective madness as their movement runs its full, sad, bloody course.
movie_title: Der Baader Meinhof Komplex (The Baader Meinhof Complex) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Tarantino's signature nastiness and his juvenile delight in shocking the audience undercut the movie's larger purpose.
Long spans of time pass between lines of dialogue, many of which seem to have been inexpertly translated from a foreign language so that they almost make sense but not quite.
Ponyo has elements of both a classic fairy tale and an environmental message movie, but it shifts as nimbly between those genres as Ponyo herself does from person to goldfish and back again.

Makes deboning a duck a feminist act and cooking a great meal a creative triumph. The stakes may not be as high as the kill-or-be-killed suspense of a summer action movie, but the sauces are way tastier.
That's as much as you should know before going into Lorna's Silence, which combines Bressonian aesthetic rigor with Hitchcockian suspense.

With top-drawer voice talent and old-fashioned two-dimensional animation that echoes the simple colors and shapes of the books, Curious George is an unexpected delight.
Trying to enumerate everything that's good about this movie could prove as labyrinthine a task as Tristram's storytelling itself.
movie_title: Tristram Shandy: A Cock & Bull Story (2005)

The New World isn't Terrence Malick's best, but it's guiding him in the right direction.
The story behind the making of The Keeper is more inspiring than the film itself.
movie_title: The Keeper: The Legend of Omar Khayyam (2005)

movie_review_blurb: This Iranian film quietly observes the title character's transformation from naïve schoolgirl to wary but proud single mother.
movie_title: I Am Taraneh, I Am Fifteen Years Old (Man, Taraneh, panzdah sal daram) (2002)

movie_review_blurb: This movie leaves us with the stale whiff of fake nostalgia and something even more odoriferous: the smell of money.

Lovett's nostalgic paean to the erotic utopia of his youth.

[A] small, beautifully faceted gem.
This documentary provides an intimate yet ultimately unsatisfying glimpse into the everyday lives of several Indian yogis.

A warm-hearted ethnic comedy in the vein of My Big Fat Greek Wedding.
This trilogy provides a sampler of three short horror films from high-profile Asian directors.
This evocative but shapeless meditation on depression and solitude in the aftermath of the 9/11 attacks is the first feature-length film by the avant-garde director Jennifer Todd Reeves.

It's a rare documentary about the Holocaust that would dare call itself The Optimists, but the title is oddly fitting for this chronicle of the Bulgarian Jews' near-miraculous survival of the Second World War.
movie_title: The Optimists: The Story of the Rescue of the Jews From Bulgaria (2001)

Ford is definitely hacking his way through something in Firewall, but it's not a computer.

For all its crude effectiveness as a true-life melodrama of survival, World Trade Center doesn't do much with 9/11, except to sentimentalize it for popular consumption.

movie_title: Talladega Nights: The Ballad of Ricky Bobby (2006)

Without a beating heart at its center, this Chest feels empty indeed.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Man's Chest (2006)

Click manages to sneak some surprisingly moving moments in between the gross-out gags and the schmaltzy resolutions.
[An] occasionally murky but always engrossing film.

For a film about death-camp survivors Forgiving Dr. Mengele is surprisingly uplifting and, at times, even lighthearted.

... an underdog tale that manages to inspire without being sappy.
... left me feeling curiously unmoved and even slightly resentful.
This spoof of sports biopics is essentially an extended improvisational skit, with a troupe of comics riffing on a central joke (the elevation of paintball to a noble calling).

The first in a projected trilogy by the Greek director Theo Angelopoulos, The Weeping Meadow is a beautiful and devastating meditation on war, history and loss.
movie_title: Trilogia: To livadi pou dakryzei (The Weeping Meadow) (2004)

Beyond the Sea (Más Allá del Mar) not to be confused with the recent Bobby Darin biopic of the same English title, tells the story of the Mariel boatlift from Cuba.

An odd bird, a slight-feeling indie film that slowly builds into a substantial meditation on contemporary politics, sexual and otherwise.

A rare hybrid: an underdog sports picture that's also a transgender fairy tale.

A somber reflection on memory, adolescence and mourning.
All but the most rabid aficionados of aviation trivia will find Fighter Pilot slow, even at 48 minutes.
Austere, rigidly formalized documentary.

Faithful to Islamic law's prohibition against representing its title character, this movie gives a prophet's-eye-view on the story.

Royston Tan's feature film debut follows five young residents of a public housing project in Singapore.
A Baxter of a movie: well meaning and mildly likable, but unlikely to sweep you off your feet.
Perhaps it was the film's irrevocable destiny to eventually find its way to the big screen, where, like its heroine, it can live out its last days in peace.
Like the Ferris wheel that serves as the setting for one of its climactic scenes, El Crimen Perfecto is a bright, gaudy and tremendously satisfying ride.
movie_title: The Perfect Crime (El Crimen Perfecto)(Crimen ferpecto) (2005)

movie_review_blurb: A State of Mind offers a rare and often chilling glimpse into the culture of North Korea.

This valentine to Hong Kong cinema should resonate with anyone who's been through the painful apprenticeship of learning the difference between life and the movies.
Despite its nearly nonstop torrent of gore, The Devil's Rejects is not really a horror film. It's a compendium of tributes and references to horror films of the past.
With its direct and nuanced treatment of the complexities of racial prejudice, sexual orientation and addiction, The Reception is a quietly ambitious and memorable film.

This inspiring documentary invites viewers to pause for a moment and consider their place in the solar system, the galaxy and the universe.

... difficult to watch, and just as difficult to forget.
Robert Rodriguez's muddled adventure movie is based on characters and themes created by his son, Racer Max, when he was 7.
movie_title: The Adventures of Sharkboy and Lavagirl in 3-D (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Like the four teenage girls at its center, The Sisterhood of the Traveling Pants makes up in charm what it lacks in sophistication.
movie_title: The Sisterhood of the Traveling Pants (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Bradley Beesley's intimate documentary traces the two-decade career of the Flaming Lips, a seminal art-rock band from Oklahoma City.

movie_title: Casuistry: The Art of Killing a Cat (2005)

movie_review_blurb: One Missed Call staggers under the weight of its director's taste for baroque excess.
A joyous celebration of sex and filmmaking.
In this dreary erotic roundelay, Caleb (Scott Lunsford) is a straight man who likes tough women.
The movie is both clever and ruthless at exposing the ratings board's inconsistencies and hypocrisy.
movie_title: This Film Is Not Yet Rated (2006)

movie_review_blurb: It's such a relief to settle into a film that lets dogs be dogs, children be children, and old-fashioned movies be old-fashioned movies.
I won't give away the plot twist, except to say that the final minute of the movie is one of the most bleak, and moving, endings I've seen in years.
The Simpsons Movie is as hard to critique as it is to resist.

Five years from now, this bland and forgettable throwaway will be remembered only for Breslin, who will by then be a poised and gifted 16-year-old actress (as long as she keeps out of Lohan-like trouble -- please, Abby!).

movie_review_blurb: The whole movie has a lightness of tone, an affection for its own cheesiness.

It has enough mind-blowing stunts to leave audience members walking out and inventing obscenity-laced catchphrases of their own.
This is the Old Testament minus the wrath, divine retribution as chicken soup for the soul -- where's the fun in that?
Angelina Jolie IS Mariane Pearl -- and that marquee-size "is" gets in the way, not of her performance, but of our ability to suspend disbelief and watch it.

The über-dream is both gorgeously animated, in Kon's shimmering, hyperreal style, and sickeningly scary.
Adrift in the windless seas of its 168-minute running time, the viewer passes through confusion and boredom into a state of Buddhist passivity.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: At Worlds End (2007)

Fresher, leaner, and faster than any action movie in years.

movie_title: Aqua Teen Hunger Force Colon Movie Film for Theaters (2007)

movie_review_blurb: That this one is even bearable is a surprise; that it's occasionally insightful and hilarious is a treat.
The TV Set is a little wonder of a movie, as smart and sad and true as any comedy I've seen this year.
What should have been a clash of two opposing moral universes instead comes off as a wan buddy flick.

It revisits [Dog Day Afternoon's] claustrophobic suspense and deep compassion for its characters -- abject, grasping everymen who truly believe they're only one act of violence away from everything they've ever wanted.
movie_title: Before the Devil Knows You're Dead (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Both a cannily constructed spy thriller and a grim kind of love story.
The movie is convinced that its man-loves-mannequin premise is uplifting, when actually it's just kinda gross.
...You resent the manipulative mechanics of the story.

Feels like no other film that you've seen before. It's cerebral and lugubrious, yet simple as a fairy tale.
movie_title: The Man From London (A Londoni Férfi) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A beautiful and formally compelling work of art.

Tony Gilroy's Michael Clayton feels so fresh, so smart, so different from the standard-issue legal thriller that it isn't until nearly an hour in that you notice how conventional a movie it actually is.

Maybe Anderson needs to shoot someone else's screenplay, to get outside his own head for a while and into another's sensibility. It's telling that his funniest and liveliest recent work was a commercial for American Express.
It leaves you wishing the oddball couple well.
Penn performs one bit of sleight-of-hand on the book that's borderline unforgivable.
An off-brand superhero movie, the cinematic equivalent of one of those generic breakfast cereals with a badly drawn squirrel for a mascot.
movie_title: Fantastic Four: Rise of the Silver Surfer (2007)

movie_review_blurb: It's a shame that The Assassination of Jesse James, a moody epic directed by Andrew Dominik and based on the 1983 novel by Ron Hansen, never goes much deeper than that tag line.
movie_title: The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Cronenberg has become such an assured director that it's a pleasure to sit back and hand yourself over to his sick and singular vision.
This is no doubt the first of many movies that will struggle to tell the stories of a war that's far from over, and even if the tale is imperfectly told, it commands our attention.
There's a genuine (and distinctly un-Larry Davidesque) sweetness to his [Jeff Garlin's] quest for love.
movie_title: I Want Someone to Eat Cheese With (2006)

movie_review_blurb: I get it that as soon as graphic novels or video games are invoked as references in a movie, we're all supposed to chuckle indulgently at the content. But I refuse to relinquish my right to be repelled by this nasty piece of work.
It falls far short as an effective sci-fi thriller, not to mention the brainy political allegory it's determined to be.
As soon as the credits start rolling, you can't wait to get out.
It's hard to account for the curious emptiness of The Nanny Diaries.
It's such a vibrant goof, so full of love both for the movies and for its cast of ridiculous characters that you forgive it the odd soggy stretch.
It's Michael Cera (heretofore best known as Jason Bateman's son on Arrested Development) whose comic timing quietly steals the show.
The result, while it may be their most ambitious and successful film in years, remains just a Coen brothers movie, a curio to collect rather than an experience to remember.

Blades of Glory does have its moments of loopy ingenuity, even if none of them goes quite far enough.
My irritation progressed through contempt, eye-rolling, and, finally, a dull despair illuminated only by the imminent prospect of dinner.
movie_title: Fur: An Imaginary Portrait of Diane Arbus (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Stranger Than Fiction is no Eternal Sunshine. But if you can look past its clunky attempt to be exactly that, there's great pleasure in watching Ferrell, like Harold, turn into someone you never knew he could be.
[Almodóvar's] once-kitschy obsession with color and surface continues to deepen into a big, bold, almost painterly style.

movie_title: Borat: Cultural Learnings of America for Make Benefit Glorious Nation of Kazakhstan (2006)

movie_review_blurb: You leave The Bridge with a new appreciation for your (relative) mental stability and a vow to make the most of your brief, ephemeral life.

Just as the ducks get lined up in a row and we're ready for the movie to reveal its true purpose -- Political satire? Paranoid dystopian fantasy? Apologia for the Bush administration? -- we suddenly realize it has none.
Makes Crash, another recent film with converging stories and a multicultural cast, look like an undergraduate term paper on race relations.

It doesn't want to explore epistemological questions about the nature of perception and memory; it just wants to mess with our heads. And as a wily, slightly sadistic chess game of a movie, it succeeds quite nicely.

It's a stylish head rush of a movie that flies by, even at two-and-a-half hours, and keeps turning the knife (and your stomach) up to the final scene.

Saints is so personal and site-specific a work that it's hard to imagine what Dito Montiel will pull out of his hat for an encore. But even if this is the only movie he has in him, the Queens kid hasn't done so badly for himself after all.
movie_title: A Guide to Recognizing Your Saints (2006)

movie_review_blurb: A sheer delight to sit through and leaves you with a whole evening's worth of impassioned conversation.

As A Scanner Darkly proves, Keanu is the Coolness -- passive blankness, leaden line delivery, and all. Let's hear it for the vague blur.

movie_title: I Think I Love My Wife (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The movie pops up out of nowhere, grabs you in its big, messy tentacles, and drags you down into murky depths, where social satire coexists with slapstick, and B-movie clichés mutate into complex metaphors.
A rich, if not completely satisfying, pleasure.

A mythic ode to righteous bellicosity. In at least one way, the film is true to the ethos of ancient Greece: It conflates moral excellence and physical beauty (which, in this movie, means being young, white, male, and fresh from the gyms of Brentwood).
Zodiac is long -- over two and a half hours -- but when it's over, you almost wish it had gone on for another 20 minutes.

Grbavica, like its heroine, is brave enough to try to find love among the ruins.
[It] won my heart for what it didn't do: all the moments it could have strained for farce or confessional self-disclosure, and instead turned its attention back to the problem at hand.

What this nasty, brutish movie left me feeling was ashamed to be American. First of all: As a folk archetype, a supervillain for our times, this is the best we can come up with? A vaguely Eurotrash schoolboy who eats people's cheeks?
The Lives of Others is the best surveillance movie since The Conversation.
Whatever substantial qualities it might once have possessed have been wasted, picked over by rumor and gossip, and sullied by the pawing of many hands.
A gruesome Cannonball Run with Piven flesh as the trophy, Smokin' Aces is a depressingly nihilistic entry in the Tarantino/Guy Ritchie/Ocean's Eleven caper genre.

What the story lacks in snap, it makes up for in sincerity. [The film's] melodrama is so poker-faced and its gore so explicit (if phony-looking) that it's hard to tell whether you're dealing with the Thai Todd Haynes or the Thai Sam Peckinpah.
movie_title: Fah talai jone (Tears of the Black Tiger) (2007)

A clever, vividly imagined, consistently funny, eye-poppingly pretty and oddly profound movie ... about Legos.
Jason Reitman forgot the tapioca.

movie_title: The Secret Life Of Walter Mitty (2013)

movie_review_blurb: So overpowering is this film's simple, horrible, and almost entirely true story that it's hard to get enough distance on 12 Years a Slave to poke at its inner workings.

If a personal memoir film by a beautiful, successful young woman from a nice Toronto family sounds to you like it can only be an excuse for self-absorbed navel-gazing, well, you must not have seen a Sarah Polley movie yet.
Takes the viewer on an event-filled but ultimately tiresome trudge through the by-now-familiar psychosexual marshes of Lars von Trier's imagination.
August: Osage County is a mess, an overcooked movie-star stew that never quite coheres into a movie.
Worth a watch despite occasional laugh-free stretches ...
It's hard to imagine any actor of his generation who could have carried off the lead role in Her other than Joaquin Phoenix.
For a movie that's all about what a swell idea it was to adapt Mary Poppins for the screen, Saving Mr. Banks seems remarkably uninterested in what made the movie special.

It's amazing how much this film does accomplish, given its modesty of both means and scale.

As timid, bland, and predictable as romantic comedies come ...
One of the most intelligent and entertaining big-studio releases of the summer so far.
movie_title: Dawn Of The Planet Of The Apes (2014)

movie_review_blurb: I can think of few feature films in the history of the medium that have explored the power, and the melancholy, of film's intimate enmeshment with time in the way Richard Linklater's Boyhood does.
[An] affectionate, candid, sometimes tough-to-watch tribute to Roger Ebert ...

Curiously moribund ...
A genial class clown of a movie.

It's a stunningly assured debut, a slyly subversive delight, and one of my favorite movies of the year so far.

The director's sometimes absurd bravado-along with Forest Whitaker's grave, wise performance in the title role-is what gives this outsized and sometimes lumbering film its irrefutable emotional power.
Does a little, sometimes shockingly little, with a lot.
Remarkable for the ease with which it positions itself outside this arena of aggressively stylized self-differentiation.

With its low-stakes chase scenes, obvious-from-the-get-go villains and nonsensical plotting, this feels more like a 96-minute-long episode of Scooby-Doo that's been laboriously translated into another language and then back into English.
Among the most profound, formally complex, and emotionally overpowering documentaries I've ever seen.

Like their Star Wars forebears, Boyega's Finn and Ridley's Rey are brave, funny, and admirable but also imperfect, uncertain, and sometimes afraid. That is to say, they're genuine, multisided characters with believable motivations.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)

movie_review_blurb: For all its borrowing and bricolage, La La Land never feels like a backward-looking or unoriginal work. Even when not every one of its risks pays off the way that first song does, this movie is bold, vital, funny, and alive.
Though it contains many scenes of prolonged suffering and a few shocking moments of graphic violence, Silence bears a contemplative stillness at its heart.
This devilishly funny and luxuriantly sensuous film is so successful as entertainment that it's hard to stop and notice the extreme degree of craft that went into its construction.
Even more impressively, Franco makes Wiseau, maybe the most unpleasant character he's ever played, someone you genuinely root for in his demented quest for greatness.
Even if you're not transported by every minute of the film's story, though, del Toro creates such a sumptuous visual world that it's impossible to take your eyes off the screen.
Filmed in luminous 35mm, as attentive to the colors and sounds of nature as it is to the beauty of art, architecture, and yes, Armie Hammer, this is the kind of movie you live in as much as watch.
But [Frances] McDormand, at age 60 one of our most gifted and least calculating actresses, fearlessly challenges us to love her character anyway.
